publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: _IS he then taken?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And brought back even now ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He was not in diſgrace?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No man more lov'd,
Nor more deſerv'd it, being the onely man.
That durſt be honeſt in this Court.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed
We have heard abroad ſir, that the State hath ſuffered,
A great change, ſince the counteſſe death.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It hath ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My five yeares abſence, hath kept me a ſtranger
So much to all the occurrents of my Country,
As you ſhall bind me for ſome ſhort relation
To make me underſtand the preſent times.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I muſt begin then with a war was made
And ſeven yeares with all cruelty continued
Upon our Flanders by the Duke of Brabant,
The cauſe grew thus: during our Earles minority,
Woolfort, (who now uſurps) was employed thither
To treat about a match betweene our Earle
And the daughter and Heire of Brabant: during which treaty
The Brabander pretends, this daughter was
Stolne from his Court, by practice of our State,
Though we are all confirm'd, 'twas a ſought quarrell
To lay an unjuſt gripe upon this Earledome,
It being here beleev'd the Duke of Brabant
Had no ſuch loſſe. This war upon't proclaim'd,
Our Earle, being then a Child, although his Father
Good Gerrard liv'd, yet in reſpect he was
Choſen by the Counteſſe favour, for her Husband
And but a Gentleman, and Floriz holding
His right unto this Country from his Mother,
The State thought fit in this defenſive war,
Woolfort being then the only man of marke,
To make him Generall.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Which place we have heard
He did diſcharge with honour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I, ſo long,
And with ſo bleſt ſucceſſes, that the Brabander
Was forc't (his treaſures waſted, and the choyce
Of his beſt men of Armes tyr'd, or cut off)
To leave the field, and ſound a baſe retreat
Back to his Countrey: but ſo broken both
In minde and meanes, er'e to make head againe,
That hitherto he ſitts downe by his loſſe,
Not daring, or for honour, or revenge
Againe to tempt his fortune. But this Victory
More broke our State, and made a deeper hurt
In Flanders, then the greateſt overthrow
She ever receiv'd: For Woolfort, now beholding
Himſelfe, and actions in the flattering glaſſe
Of ſelfe-deſervings, and that cheriſh't by
The ſtrong aſſurance of his power, for then
All Captaines of the Army, were his creatures,
The common Souldier too at his devotion,
Made ſo by full indulgence to their rapines
And ſecret bounties, this ſtrength too well knowne
And what it could effect, ſoone put in practice,
As furtherd by the child-hood of the Earle
And their improvidence, that might have peirc't
The heart of his deſignes, gave him occaſion
To ſieze the whole, and in that plight you find it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, I receive the knowledge of thus much
As a choyce favour from you

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Onely I muſt add
Bruges holds out.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Whether ſir, I am going
For there laſt night I had a ſhip put in,
And my horſe waits me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I wiſh you a good journey.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What? Hubert ſtealing from me? who diſarm'd him,
It was more then I commanded; take your ſword,
I am beſt guarded with it in your hand,
I have ſeene you uſe it nobly.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And will turne it
On mine owne boſom, ere it ſhall be drawne
Vnworthily or rudely.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: VVould you leave me
VVithout a farwell Hubert? fly a friend
Vnwearied in his ſtudy to advance you?
VVhat have I ev'r poſſeſſed which was not yours?
Or either did not court you to command it?
Who ever yet arriv'd to any grace,
Reward or truſt from me, but his approaches
Wereby your faire reports of him prefer'd?
And what is more I made my ſelfe your Servant,
In making you the Maſter of thoſe ſecrets
Which not the rack of conſcience could draw from me,
Nor I, when I askt mercy, truſt my prayers with;
Yet after theſe aſſurances of love,
Theſe tyes and bonds of freindſhip, to forſake me,
Forſake me as an enemie? come you muſt
Give me a reaſon.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, and ſo I will,
If I may do't in privat: and you heare it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: All leave the roome: you have your will, ſet downe
And uſe the liberty of our firſt friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Friendſhip? when you prov'd Traitor firſt, that vaniſh'd
Nor do I owe you any thought, but hate,
I know my flight hath forfeited my head;
And ſo I may make you firſt underſtand
What a ſtrange monſter you have made your ſelfe,
I welcome it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: To me this is ſtrange language.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: To you? why what are you?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Your Prince and Maſter,
The Earle of Flaunders.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By a proper title,
Rais'd to it by cunning circumvention, force,
Blood, and proſcriptions.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: And in all this wiſedome;
Had I not reaſon? when by Gerrards plotts
I ſhould haue firſt been call'd to a ſtrict accop
How, and which way I had conſum'd that maſſe
Of money, as they terme it in the warr,
VVho underhand, had by his Miniſters
Detracted my great action, made my faith
And loyalty ſo ſuſpected in which failing
He ſought my life by practice.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With what fore-head,
Do you ſpeake this to me? who (as I know't)
Muſt, and will ſay 'tis falſe,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My guard there.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, you bad me ſit, & promis'd you would heare
Which I now ſay you ſhall, not a ſound more,
For I that am contemner of mine owne,
Am Maſter of your life; then heer's a Sword
Betweene you, and all aydes Sir, though you blind
The credulous beaſt, the multitude, you paſſe not
Theſe groſſe untruthes on me.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: How? groſſe untruthes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I, and it is favourable language,
They had bin in a meane man lyes, and foule ones.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You take ſtrange licence.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, were not thoſe rumours
Of being called unto your anſwers, ſpread
By your owne followers; and weake Gerrard wrought
(But by your cunnig practiſe) to be beleeve
That you were dangerous; yet not to be
Puniſh'd by any formall courſe of law,
But firſt to be made ſure, and have your crimes
Layd open after, which your queint traine taking
You fled unto the Campe, and there crav'd humbly
Protection for your innocent life, and that,
Since you had ſcap'd the fury of the warr,
You might not fall by treaſon, and for proofe,
You did not for your owne ends make this danger;
Some that had been before, by you ſubornd,
Came forth and tooke their oathes they had been hir'd
By Gerrard to your murther. This once heard,
And eaſily beleev'd, th'inraged Souldier
Seeing no further then the outward man,
Snatch'd haſtily his Armes, ran to the Court,
Kill'd all that made reſiſtance, cut in pieces
Such as were Servants, or thought friends to Gerrard,
Vowing the like to him.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Will you yet end?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Which he foreſeeing, with his Sonne, the Earle,
Forſooke the Citty; and by ſecret wayes
As you give out, and we would gladly have it,
Eſcap'd their fury: though 'tis more then fear'd
They fell among the reſt; Nor ſtand you there
To let us onely mourne, the impious meanes
By which you got it, but your cruelties ſince
So farr tranſcend your former bloody ills,
As if compar'd, they onely would appeare
Eſſayes of miſchiefe; do not ſtop your eares,
More are behind yet.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: O repeat them not,
'Tis hell to heare them nam'd.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You ſhould have thought,
That hell would be your puniſhment when you did them,
A Prince, in nothing but your princely luſts,
And boundleſſe rapines.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: No more I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Who was the Lord of houſe or land, that ſtood
Within the proſpect of your coveteous eye?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You are in this to me a greater Tyrant,
Then ere I was to any.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I end thus
The generall griefe, now to my private wrong;
The loſſe of Gerrards daughter Jaqueline:
The hop'd for partner of my lawfull bed,
Your cruelty hath frighted from mine armes;
And her, I now was wandring to recouer.
Thinke you that I had reaſon now to leave you,
When you are growne ſo juſtly odious,
That ev'n my ſtay here with your grace and favour,
Makes my life irckſome? here ſurely take it,
And do me but this fruite of all your frendſhip,
That I may dye by you, and not your hang-man.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Oh Hubert, theſe your wordes and reaſons have
As well drawne drops of blood from my griev'd hart,
As theſe teares from mine eyes;
Deſpiſe them not
By all that's ſacred, I am ſerious Hubert,
You now have made me ſenſible, what furyes,
Whips, hangmen, and tormentors a bad man
Do's ever beare about him: let the good
That you this day have done, be ever numberd,
The firſt of your beſt actions;
Can you think,
Where Floriz is or Gerrard, or your love,
Or any elſe, or all that are proſcrib'd?
I will reſigne, what I uſurpe, or have
Unjuſtly forc'd; the dayes I have to live
Are too too few to make them ſatisfaction
With any penitence: yet I vow to practiſe
All of a man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O that your hart and tongue
Did not now differ!

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: By my griefes they do not
Nake the good paines to ſearch them out; 'tis worth it,
You have made cleane a Leper: truſt me you have,
And made me once more fit for the ſociety,
I hope of good men.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, do not abuſe
My aptneſſe to beleeve.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Suſpect not you
A faith that's built upon ſo true a ſorrow,
Make your owne ſafetyes: aske them all the ties
Humanity can give, Hemskirick too ſhall
Along with you to this ſo wiſh'd diſcovery,
And in my name profeſs all that you promiſe;
And I will give you this helpe to't: I have
Of late receiv'd certaine intelligence,
That ſome of them are in or about Bruges
To be found out: which I did then interpret,
The cauſe of that Townes ſtanding out againſt me;
But now am glad, it may direct your purpoſe
Of giving them their ſafety, and mee peace.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Be conſtant to your goodneſſe, & you have it. Ex.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: T'is much that you deliver of this Goſwin.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: But ſhort of what I could, yet have the Country
Confirmd it true, and by a generall oath,
And not a man hazard his credit in it:
He beares himſelfe with ſuch a confidence
As if he were the Maſter of the Sea;
And not a winde upon the Sailers compaſſe,
But from one part or other, was his factor,
To bring him in the beſt commodities,
Merchant e're venturd for:
'Tis ſtrange,
And yet;
This do's in him deſerve the leaſt of wonder,
Compared with other his peculiar faſhions,
Which all admire: he's young, and rich, at leaſt
Thus far reputed ſo, that ſince he liv'd
In Bruges, there was never brought to harbour
So rich a Bottome, but his bill would paſſe
Unqueſtion'd for her lading.

sp.speaker: 3 M●r.
sp.l: Yet he ſtill
Continues a good man.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: So good, that but
To doubt him, would be held an injury
Or rather malice, with the beſt that traffique;
But this is nothing, a great ſtocke, and fortune,
Crowning his judgement in his undertakings
May keep him upright that way: But that wealth
Should want the power to make him dote on it,
Or youth teach him to wrong it, beſt commends
His conſtant temper; for his outward habit
'Tis ſutable to his preſent courſe of life:
His table furniſh'd well, but not with dainties
That pleaſe the appetite only for their rareneſſe,
Or the deare price: nor given to wine or women,
Beyond his health, or warrant of a man,
I meane a good one: and ſo loves his ſtate
He will not hazard it at play; nor lend
Upon the aſſurance of a well-pen'd Letter,
Although a challenge ſecond the denyall
From ſuch as make th'opinion of their valour
Their meanes of feeding.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: Theſe are wayes to thrive,
And the meanes not curs'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: What follows this,
Makes many Venturers with him, in their wiſhes,
For his proſperity: for when deſert
Or reaſon leads him to be liberall,
His noble mind and ready hand contend
Which can add moſt to his free curteſies,
Or in their worth, or ſpeed to make them ſo.
Is there a Virgin of good fame wants dowre?
He is a father to her; or a Souldier
That in his Countreyes ſervice, from the warre
Hath brought him only ſcars, and want? his houſe
Receives him, and relieves him, with that care
As if what he poſſes'd had been laid up
For ſuch good uſes, and he ſteward of it.
But I ſhould looſe my ſelfe to ſpeake him further
And ſtale in my relation, the much good
You may be witneſſe of, if your remove
From Brugis, be not ſpeedy.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: This report
I do aſſure you will not haſten it,
Nor would I wiſh a better man to deale with
For what I am to part with.

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Never doubt it,
He is your man and ours, only I wiſh
His too much forwardneſſe to embrace all bargains
Sucke him not in the end.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: Have better hopes,
For my part I am confident; here he comes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I take it at your own rates: your wine of Cyprus,
But for your Candy ſugars, they have met
With ſuch foule weather, and are priz'd ſo high
I cannot ſave in them.

sp.speaker: 4 Mer.
sp.l: I am unwilling
To ſeeke another Chap-man: make me offer
Of ſomething near my price, that may aſſure me
You can deale for them.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I both can, and will,
But not with too much loſſe; your bill of lading
Speakes of two hundred cheſts, valued by you
At thirty thouſand gilders. I will have them
At twenty eight; ſo, in the payment of
Three thouſand ſterling, you fall only in
Two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: You know, they are ſo cheape.—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why looke you; I'le deale fairly, ther's in priſon,
And at your ſuite, a Pirat, but unable
To make you ſatisfaction, and paſt hope
To live a weeke, if you ſhould proſecute
What you can prove againſt him: ſet him free,
And you ſhall have your money to a Stiver,
And preſent payment.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: This is above wonder,
A Merchant of your ranke, that have at Sea
So many Bottoms in the danger of
Theſe water-Theeves, ſhould be a meanes to ſave 'em
It more importing you for your owne ſafety
To be at charge to ſcoure the Sea of them
Then ſtay the ſword of Juſtice, that is ready
To fall on one ſo conſcious of his guilt
That he dares not deny it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You miſtake me,
If you thinke I would cheriſh in this Captaine
The wrong he did to you, or any man;
I was lately with him, (having firſt, from others
True teſtimony been aſſured, a man
Of more deſert never put from the ſhore)
I read his letters of Mart from this State granted
For the recovery of ſuch loſſes, as
He had receiv'd in Spain, 'twas that he aim'd at,
Not at three tuns of wine, bisket, or beefe,
Which his neceſſity made him take from you.
If he had pillag'd you neare, or ſunke your ſhip,
Or thrown your men o'r-boord, then he deſerv'd
The Lawes extreameſt rigour: But ſince want
Of what he could not live without, compel'd him
To that he did (which yet our State calls death)
I pitty his misfortune; and to worke you
To ſome compaſſion of them, I come up
To your own price: ſave him, the goods are mine;
If not, ſeeke elſe-where, I'le not deale for them.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: Well Sir, for your love, I will once be lead
To change my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For your profit rather.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: I'le preſently make meanes for his diſcharge,
Till when, I leave you.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: What do you thinke of this?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: As of a deed of noble pitty: guided
By a ſtrong judgement.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: Save you Maſter Goſwin.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good day to all.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: We bring you the refuſall
Of more Commodities.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Are you the owners
Of the ſhip that laſtnight put into the Harbour?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: Both of the Ship, and lading.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's the fraught?

sp.speaker: 3 Mar.
sp.l: And cloath of Gold brought from Camball.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rich lading,
For which I were your Chapman, but I am
Already out of caſh.

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: I'le give you day
For the moiety of all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Sixe moneths.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a faire offer: which (if we agree
About the prizes) I, with thanks accept of,
And will make preſent payment of the reſt;
Some two hours hence I'le come aboord.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: The Gunner ſhall ſpeake you welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'le not faile,

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Good morrow. Exit Merch.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven grant my Ships a ſafe returne, before
The day of this great payment: as they are
Expected three moneths ſooner: and my credite
Stands good with all the world. Enter Gerrard.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bleſſe my good Maſter,
The prayers of your poor Beadſ-man ever ſhall
Be ſent up for you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: God 'a mercy Clauſe,
Ther's ſomething to put thee in minde hereafter
To thinke of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: May he that gave it you
Reward you for it, with encreaſe, good Maſter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thrive the better for thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I hope ſo.
This three yeares have I fed upon your bounties,
And by the fire of your bleſt charity warm'd me,
And yet, good Maſter, pardon me, that muſt,
Though I have now receiv'd your almes, preſume
To make one ſute more to you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is't Clauſe?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yet do not think me impudent I beſeech you,
Since hitherto your charity hath prevented
My begging your reliefe, 'tis not for money
Nor cloaths (good Maſter) but your good word for me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That thou ſhalt have, Clauſe, for I think thee honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To morrow then (dear M^r.) take the trouble
Of walking early unto Beggars Buſh,
And as you ſee me, among others (Brethren
In my affliction) when you are demanded
Which you like beſt among us, point out me,
And then paſſe by, as if you knew me not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But what will that advantage thee?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O much Sir,
'Twill give me the preheminence of the reſt,
Make me a King among 'em, and protect me,
From all abuſe, ſuch as are ſtronger, might
Offer my age; Sir, at your better leizure
I will informe you further of the good
It may do to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Troth thou mak'ſt me wonder;
Have you a King and Common-wealth among you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We have, & there are States are governd worſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ambition among Beggars?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.l: Many great ones
Would part with halfe their States, to have the place,
And credit to beg in the firſt file, Maſter:
But ſhall I be ſo much bound to your furtherance
In my Petition?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That thou ſhalt not miſſe of,
Nor any worldly cane make me forget it,
I will be early there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe my Maſter. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Higgen, Ferret, Prig, Clauſe, Jaculine, Snap, Gynkes, and other Beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: COme Princes of the ragged regiment,
You 'o the blood, Prig my moſt upright Lord,
And theſe (what name or title, e're they beare)
Jarkman, or Patrico, Cranke, or Clapperdudgeon.
Frater, or Abram-man; I ſpeake to all
That ſtand in faire Election for the title
Of King of Beggars, with the command adjoyning,
Higgen, your Orator, in this Inter-regnum,
That whilom was your Dommerer, doth beſeech you
All to ſtand faire, and put your ſelves in ranke,
That the firſt Commer, may at his firſt view
Make a free choiſe, to ſay up the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Fer. Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis done Lord Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thankes to Prince Prig, Prince Ferret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, pray my Maſters all, Ferret be choſen
Ye'ar like to have a mercifull mild Prince of me.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A very tyrant, I, an arrant tyrant.
If e're I come to reigne; therefore looke to't,
Except you do provide me hum enough
And Lour to bouze with: I muſt have my Capons
And Turkeys brought me in, with my green Geeſe,
And Ducklings i'th ſeaſon: fine fat chickens,
Or if you chance where an eye of tame Pheſants
Or Partridges are kept, ſee they be mine,
Or ſtraight I ſeize on all your priviledge,
Places, revenues, offices, as forfeit,
Call in your crutches, wooden legs, falſe bellyes,
Forc'd eyes and teeth, with your dead arms; not leave you
A durty clout to beg with o' your heads,
Or an old rag with Butter, Frankinſence,
Brimſtone and Rozen, birdlime, blood, and creame,
To make you an old ſore; not ſo much ſope
As you may fome with i'th Falling-ſickneſſe;
The very bag you beare, and the brown diſh
Shall be eſcheated. All your daintieſt dells too
I will deflowr, and take your deareſt Doxyes
From your warme ſides; and then ſome one cold night
I'le watch you what olde barne you goe to rooſt in,
And there I'le ſmoother you all i'th muſty hay.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is tyrant-like indeed: But what would Ginkes
Or Clauſe be here, if either of them ſhould raigne?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Beſt aske an aſſe, if he were made a Camell,
What he would be; or a dog, and he were a Lyon.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: I care not what you are, Sirs, I ſhall be
A Begger, ſtill, I am ſure, find my ſelfe there.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: O here a Judge comes.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Cry, a Judge, a Judge.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What aile you Sirs? what means this out cry?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Maſter
A ſort of poor ſoules met: Gods fools, good Maſter,
Have had ſome little variance amongſt our ſelves
Who ſhould be honeſteſt of us; and which lives
Uprighteſt in his call: Now, 'cauſe we thought
We ne're ſhould gree on't our ſelves, becauſe
Indeed 'tis hard to ſay: we all diſſolv'd, to put it
To whom that ſhould come next, and that's your Maſterſhip,
Who, I hope, will termine it as your mind ſerves you,
Right, and no otherwiſe we aske it: which?
Which does your Worſhip thinke is he? ſweet Maſter
Looke over us all, and tell us; we are ſeven of us,
Like to the ſeven wiſe Maſters, or the Planets.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I ſhould judge this the man with the grave beard,
And if he be not—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bleſſe you, good Maſter, bleſſe you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I would he were: there's ſomething too, amongſt you
To keep you all honeſt. Exit

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: King of heaven goe with you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Now good reward him,
May he never want it, to comfort ſtill the poor, in a good houre.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is 't? ſee: Snap ha's got it.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A good crown, marry:

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A crown of gold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For our new King: good luck.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: To the common treaſury with it; if 't be gold,
Thither it muſt.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Spoke like a Patriot, Ferret—
King Clauſe. I bid God ſave thee firſt, firſt, Clauſe,
After this golden token of a crowne;
Wher's Oratour Higgen with his gratuling ſpeech now,
In all our names?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here he is pumping for it.

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: H' has cough'd the ſecond time, 'tis but once more
And then it comes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So, out with all: expect now—

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: That thou art choſen, venerable Clauſe,
Our King and Soveraign; Monarch o'th Maunders.
Thus we throw up our Nab-cheats, firſt for joy,
And then our filches; laſt, we clap our fambles,
Three ſubject ſignes, we do it without envy:
For who is he here did not wiſh thee choſen
Now thou art choſen? aske 'em: all will ſay ſo,
Nay ſwear't: 'tis for the King, but let that paſſe;
When laſt in conference at the bouzing ken
This other day we ſate about our dead Prince
Of famous memory: (reſt, goe with his rags:)
And that I ſaw thee at the tables end,
Riſe mov'd, and gravely leaning on one Crutch,
Lift the other like a Scepter at my head,
I then preſag'd thou ſhortly wouldſt be King
And now thou art ſo: but what need preſage,
To us, that might have read it, in thy beard,
As well, as he that choſe thee? by that beard
Thou wert found out, and mark'd for Soveraignty.
O happy beard! but happier Prince, whoſe beard,
Was ſo remark'd, as marked out our Prince,
Not bating us a haire. Long may it grow,
And thick, and faire, that who lives under it,
May live as ſafe, as under Beggars Buſh,
Of which this is the thing, that but the type.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Excellent, excellent oratour, forward good Higgen
Give him leave to ſpit: the fine, well-ſpoken Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is the beard, the buſh, or buſhy-beard,
Under whoſe gold and ſilver raigne 'twas ſaid
So many ages ſince, we all ſhould ſmile
On impoſitions, taxes, grievances,
Knots in a State, and whips unto a Subject,
Lye lurking in this Beard, but all hem'd out:
If now, the Beard be ſuch, what is the Prince
That owes the Beard? a Father; no, a Grandfather;
Nay the great Grand-father of you his people.
He will not force away your hens, your bacon,
When you have ventur'd hard for't, nor take from you
The fatteſt of your puddings: under him
Each man ſhall eate his own ſtolne eggs, and butter,
In his owne ſhade, or ſun-ſhine, and enjoy
His owne deare Dell, Doxy, or Mort, at night
In his own ſtraw, with his owne ſhirt, or ſheet,
That he hath filch'd that day, I, and poſſeſſe
What he can purchaſe, backe, or belly-cheats
To his own prop: he will have no purveyers
For Pigs, and poultry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That we muſt have, my learned Oratour,
It is our will, and every man to keep
In his own path and circuite.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you heare?
You muſt hereafter maund on your own pads he ſaies.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And what they get there, is their owne, beſides
To give good words.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you marke? to cut bene whids,
That is the ſecond Law.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And keepe a-foote
The humble, and the common phraſe of begging,
Leſt men diſcover us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes; and cry ſometimes,
To move compaſſion: Sir, there is a table,
That doth command all theſe things, and enjoyns 'em;
Be perfect in their crutches: their fain'd plaiſters,
And their true paſ-ports, with the ways to ſtammer,
And to be dumb, and deafe, and blind, and lame,
There, all the halting paces are ſet downe,
I'th learned language.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thither I refer them,
Thoſe, you at leiſure ſhall interpret to them,
We love no heapes of lawes, where few will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O gracious Prince, 'ſave, 'ſave the good K. Clauſe.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A Song to crowne him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Set a Centinell out firſt.

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: The word?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: A Cove comes, and fumbumbis to it.— Strike.

sp.l: CAſt our Caps and cares away: this is Beggars Holli-day,
At the Crowning of our King, thus we ever dance & ſing.
In the world looke out and ſee: where ſo happy a Prince as he?
Where the Nation live ſo free, and ſo merry as do we?
Be it peace, or be it war, here at liberty we are,
And enjoy our eaſe and reſt; To the field we are not preſt;
Nor are called into the Towne, to be troubled with the Gowne.
Hang all Offices we cry, and the Magiſtrate too, by;
When the Subſidies encreaſt, we are not a penny ceaſt.
Nor will any goe to law, with the Beggar for a ſtraw.
All which happineſſe he brags, he doth owe unto his rags.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A Cove: Fumbumbis.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your poſtures; arme:

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yonder's the Towne: I ſee it.

sp.speaker: Hemsk.
sp.l: Ther's our danger
Indeed afore us, if our ſhadows ſave not.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Bleſſe your good Worſhips:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One ſmall piece of money.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Amongſt us all poore wretches:

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blinde, and lame,

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: For his ſake that gives all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Pittifull Worſhips;

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: One little doyt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: King, by your leave, where are you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To buy a litle bread,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To feed ſo many
Mouths, as will ever pray for you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here be ſeven of us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Seven, good Maſter, ô remember ſeven,
Seven bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Remember, gentle Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Gainſt ſeven deadly ſins,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And ſeven ſleepers.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: If they be hard of heart, and will give nothing—
Alas, we had not a charity this three dayes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ther's amongſt you all?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Heaven reward you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Lord, reward you?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Prince of pitty bleſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do I ſee? or is't my fancy that would have it ſo?
Ha? 'tis her face: come hither Maid.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What ha', you
Bells for my ſquirrell? I ha' giv'n Bun meat,
You do not love me, do you? catch me a butterfly,
And I'le love you againe; when? can you tell?
Peace, we go a birding: I ſhall have a fine thing.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Her voyce too ſayes the ſame; but for my head
I would not that her manners, were ſo chang'd,
Heare me thou honeſt fellow; what's this Mayden,
That lives amongſt you here?

sp.speaker: Gincks.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How? nothing but ſignes?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This ſtrange,
I would ſaine have it her, but not her thus.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: He is de-de-de-de-de-de-deafe, and du-du-dude—dumb Sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Slid they did all ſpeak plain ev'n now me thought
Do'ſt thou know this ſame Maid?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: Why, why, why, why, which, gu, gu, gu, gu, Gods foole
She was bo-bo-bo-bo-borne at the barne younder,
By-be-be-be-be-Beggars Buſh-bo-bo-Buſh
Her name is, My-my-my-my-my-match: ſo was her Mo-mo-mo-Mothers too-too

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I underſtand no word ſhe ſayes; how long
Has ſhe been here?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.p: Lo-lo-long enough to be ni-ni-nigled: and ſhe ha' go-go-go-good luck,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I muſt be better inform'd, then by this way.
Here was another face too, that I mark'd
O the old mans: but they are vaniſh'd all
Moſt ſodainly: I will come here againe,
O, that I were ſo happy, as to finde it,
What I yet hope? it is put on.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What meane you Sir,
To ſtay there with that ſtammerer?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell friend,—
It will be worth returne, to ſearch: Come,
Protect us our diſguize now, pre'thee Hemskirck
If we be taken, how do'ſt thou imagine
This Towne will uſe us, that hath ſtood ſo long
Out, againſt Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ev'n to hang us forth
Upon their walls a ſunning, to make Crowes meate,
If I were not aſſur'd 'o the Burgomaſter,
And had a pretty skuys, to ſee a niece there,
I ſhould ſcarce venture.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come 'tis now too late
To looke back at the ports: good luck, and enter. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Still blow'ſt thou there? and from all other parts,
Do all my Agents ſleepe? that nothing comes?
Ther's a conſpiracy of windes, and ſervants:
If not of Elements, to ha' me breake;
What ſhould I thinke unleſſe the Seas, and Sandes
Had ſwallow'd up my ſhips? or fire had ſpoyl'd
My ware-houſes? or death devour'd my Facto
I muſt ha' had ſome returnes;

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: 'Saue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Save you.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: No newes, yet 'o your Ships?

sp.speaker: o.
sp.l: Not any yet Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir: what a voyce was here now?
This was one paſſing bell, a thouſand ravens
Sung in that man now, to preſage my ruines.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.p: Goſwin, good day, theſe winds, are very conſtant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They are ſo Sir; to hurt—

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: Ha? you had no letters,
Lately from England, nor from Denmark?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: This winde brings them; nor no newes over land,
Through Spaine, from the Straights?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Not any.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I am ſorry Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They talke me downe: and as 'tis ſaid, of Vultures
They ſent a feild fought, and do ſmell the carkaſſes
By many hundred miles: So do theſe, my wracks
At greater diſtances: why thy will heaven
Come on, and be: yet if thou pleaſe, preſerve me;
But in my owne adventure, here at home,
Of my chaſt love, to keep me worthy of her,
It ſhall be put in ſcale againſt all ill fortunes:
I am not broken yet: nor ſhould I fall,
Me thinkes with leſſe then that, that ruines all. Exit

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter. Van-dunck. Hubert. Hemſkirck. and Margaret. Boores.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Captaine you are welcome; ſo is this your friend
Moſt ſafely welcome, though our Towne ſtand out
Againſt your Maſter; you ſhall finde good quarter:
The troth is, we not love him: Meg: ſome wine,
Let's talke a little treaſon, If we can
Talk treaſon, gain' the Traitors; by your leave, Gentlemen
We here in Brugis, thinke he do's uſurpe,
And therefore I am bold with him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, your boldneſſe,
Happely becomes your mouth, but not our eares,
While we are his ſervants; And as we come here,
Not to aske queſtions, walke forth on your walls;
Viſit your courtes of guard, view your Munition,
Aske of your corne-proviſions, nor enquire
Into the leaſt, as ſpies upon your ſtrengthes,
So let's entreate, we may receive from you
Nothing in paſſage or diſcourſe, but what
We may with gladneſſe, and our honeſties here,
And that ſhall ſeale our welcome.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Good: let's drinke then,

sp.speaker: Mage:
sp.l: fill out, I keep mine old pearle ſtill Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hang faſt man.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Old Iewels, commend their keeper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Heer's to you with a hart, my Captaines friend,
With a good heart, and if this make us ſpeake
Bold words, anon: 'tis all under the Roſe
Forgotten: drowne all memory, when we drinke

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis freely ſpoken noble Burgomaſter,
I'le do you right.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay Sir mine heire Van-dunck,
Is a true Stateſmen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Fill my Captaines cup there, ô that your Maſter Woolfort.
Had been an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Under the Roſe.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Heer's to you Marget.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcom; welcom Captaine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well ſaid my pearle ſtill,

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well ſaid, my pearl ſtill,

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And how does my Niece?
Almoſt a woman; I thinke? This friend of mine,
I drew along with me, through ſo much hazard,
Only to ſee her: ſhe was my errand.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I, a kinde Uncle you are (fill him his glaſſe)
That in ſeven yeares, could not find leizure.—

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No,
It's not ſo much.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'le bate you nev'r an houre on't,
I was before the Brabander gan his war,
For moone-ſhine, i'th water there, his daughter
That never was loſt: yet you could not finde time
To ſee a Kinſwoman: But ſhee is worth the ſeeing Sir.
Now you are come, you aske if ſhe were a woman?
Shee is a woman Sir; fetch her forth Margee. Exit Marg.
And a fine woman, and has Suitors.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How?
What Suitors are they.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Bachellors: young Burgers:
And one, a gallant, the young Prince of Merchants,
We call him here, in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How? a Merchant?
I thought Van-doncke, you had underſtood me better,
And my Niece too, ſo truſted to you by me:
Then t'admit of ſuch in name of Suitors.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Such? he is ſuch a ſuch, as were ſhe mine
I'de give him thirty thouſand crownes with her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: But the ſame things Sir, fit not you and me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Why, give's ſome wine, then; This will fit us all:
Here's to you ſtill, my Captains friend: All out:
And ſtill, would Woolfort were an honeſt man,
Under the Roſe, I ſpeake it: but this Merchant
Is a brave boy: he lives ſo, i'the towne here,
We know not what to thinke on him: At ſometimes
We feare he will be Bankrupt; he do's ſtretch
Tenter his credite ſo; embraces all,
And too't, the winds have been contrary, long.
But then, if he ſhould have all his returnes,
We thinke he would be a King, and are halfe ſure on't.
Your Maſter is a Traytor, for all this
Under the Roſe: here's to you; and uſurps
The Earldome ftom a better man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I marry Sir,
Where is that man?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay ſoft: and I could tell you
'Tis ten to one I would not: here's my hand,
I love not Woolfort: ſit you ſtill, with that:
Here comes my Captaine againe, and his fine Niece,
And ther's my Merchant: view him well, fill wine here.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You muſt not only know me for your Uncle,
Now, but obey me; you, goe caſt your ſelfe
Away, upon a dunghill here? a Merchant?
A petty fellow? one that makes this trade
With oathes and perjuries?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is that you ſay Sir?
If it be me you ſpeake of; as your eye
Seemes to direct: I wiſh you would ſpeake to me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I do ſay, ſhe is no Merchandize,
Will that ſuffice you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Merchandize good Sir,
Though ye be Kinſman to her: take no leave thence
To uſe me with contempt: I ever thought
Your Niece above all price.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And do ſo ſtill, Sir,
I aſſure you, her rate's at more then you are worth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You do not know, what a Gentleman's worth ſir,
Nor can you value him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Well ſaid Merchant.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay,
Let him alone, and ply your matter.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A Genntleman?
What, o' the wool-pack? or the Sugar-cheſt?
Or liſts of Velvet? which is't? pound, or yard,
You vent your Gentry by?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O Hemskirke, fye.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, do not mind 'em drink, he is no Woolfort,
Captaine, I adviſe you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Alas, my pretty man,
I think't be angry, by its looke: Come hither,
Turne this way, a little: if it were the blood
Of Charlemaine, as 't may (for ought I know)
Be ſome good Botchers iſſue, here in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay: I'me not certaine of that; of this I am,
If it once buy, and ſell, its Gentry is gone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You are angry, though ye laugh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, now 'tis pitty
Of your poor argument. Do not you, the Lords,
Of land (if you be any) ſell the graſſe,
The corne, the ſtraw, the milke, the cheeſe?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: And butter:
Remember butter; doe not leave out butter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The Beefs and Muttons that your grounds are ſtor'd with?
Swine, with the very maſt, beſide the woods?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No, for thoſe ſordid uſes, we have Tenants,
Or elſe our Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Have not we Sir, Chap-men,
And Factors, then to anſwer theſe? your errour
Fetch'd from the Heralds A B C. and ſaid over
With your Court faces, once an houre, ſhall never
Make me miſtake my ſelfe. Do not your Lawyers
Sell all their practiſe, as your Prieſts their prayers?
What is not bought, and ſold? The company
That you had laſt, what had you fort, y'faith?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You now grow ſawcy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sure I have been bred
Still, with my honeſt liberty, and muſt uſe it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Upon your equals, then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, he that will
Provoke me firſt, doth make himſelfe my equall.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Do ye heare? no more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes Sir, this little, I pray you,
And't ſhall be aſide, then after, as you pleaſe,
You appeare the Uncle, ſ●ir, to her I love,
More then mine eyes; and I have heard your ſcorns
With ſo much ſcoffing, and ſo much ſhame,
As each ſtrive which is greater: But, beleeve me
I ſuck'd not in this patience with my milke.
Do not preſume, becauſe you ſee me young,
Or caſt deſpights on my profeſſion
For the civility and tameneſſe of it.
A good man beares a contumely worſe
Then he would do an injury. Proceed not
To my offence: wrong is not ſtill ſucceſſefull,
Indeed it is not: I would approach your Kinſ-woman
With all reſpect, done to your ſelfe and her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Away Companion: handling her? take that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay, I do love no blows, ſir, there's exchange.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Hold ſir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O murther.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Help, my Goſwin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Man.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Let 'em alone; my life for one.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay come
If you have will.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: None to offend you, I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He that had, thank himſelf: not hand her? yes Sir,
And claſpe her, and embrace her; and (would ſhe
Now goe with me) bear her through all her race,
Her Father, Brethren, and her Uncles, arme'd,
And all their Nephews, though they ſtood a wood
Of pikes, and wall of Canon: kiſſe me Gertrude,
Quake not, but kiſſe me.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Kiſſe him, girle, I bid you;
My Merchant royall; feare no Uncles: hang 'em,
Hang up all Uncles: Are we not in Bruges?
Under the Roſe here?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In this circle, Love,
Thou are as ſafe, as in a towre of braſſe;
Let ſuch as do wrong, feare.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I, that's good,
Let Woolfort looke to that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, here ſhe ſtands,
Your Niece, and my beloved. One of theſe titles
She muſt apply to; if unto the laſt,
Not all the anger can be ſent unto her,
In frowne, or voyce, or other art, ſhall force her,
Had Hercules a hand in't: Come, my Joy,
Say thou art mine, aloud Love, and profeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Doe: and I drinke to it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prethee ſay ſo, Love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Twould take away the honour from my bluſhes:
Doe not you play the Tyrant, ſweet: they ſpeake it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I thanke you Niece.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, thanke her for your life,
And fetch your ſword within.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You inſult too much
With your good fortune, Sir. Exit Florez.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A brave cleare ſpirit;
Hemskirke, you were too blame: a civill habit
Oft covers a good man: and you may meete
In perſon of a Merchant, with a ſoule
As reſolute, and free, and all wayes worthy,
As elſe in any file of man-kinde: pray you,
What meant you ſo to ſlight him?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis done now,
Aske no more of it; I muſt ſuffer. Exit Hemskirk.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This,
Is ſtill the puniſhment of raſhneſſe, ſorrow;
Well; I muſt to the woods, for nothing here
Will be got out. There, I may chance to learne
Somewhat to help my enquiries further.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ha?
A Looking-glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How now, brave Burgo-maſter?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I love no Woolforts, and my names Vandoncke,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Van-drunke it's rather: Come, go ſleep within.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Earle Florez is right heir, and this ſame Woolfort
Under the Roſe I ſpeake it. —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Very hardly.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Uſurpes: and a ranke Traitor, as ever breath'd,
And all that do uphold him. Let me goe,
No man ſhall hold me, that upholds him;
Doe you uphold him?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Then hold me up. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I preſume, you have a ſword of your owne,
That can ſo handle anothers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith you may Sir.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: And ye have made me have ſo much better thoughts of you
As I am bound to call you forth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For what Sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To the repairing of mine honour, & hurt here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Expreſſe your way.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By fight, and ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You have your will: Require you any more?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That you be ſecret: and come ſingle.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As you are the Gentlemā you would be thought.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Without the Conjuration: and I'le bring
Only my ſword, which I will fit to yours,
I'le take his length within.

sp.speaker: Hem
sp.l: Your place now Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By the Sand-hills.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, nearer to the woods,
If you thought ſo, were fitter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: There, then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: good.
Your time?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twixt ſeven and eight.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You'l give me Sir
Cauſe to report you worthy of my Niece,
If you come, like your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I do not
Let no man think to call me unworthy firſt,
I'le doe't my ſelfe: and juſtly wiſh to want her.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: COme, Engliſh beer Hoſteſs, Engliſh beer bi'th belly

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Start beer boy, ſtout & ſtrong beer: ſo, ſit downe Lads,
And drinke me upſey-Dutch:
Frollicke, and feare not.

body.stage: Enter Higgen like a Sow-gelder, ſinging.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any worke for the Sow-gelder, boa,
My horne goes to high to low, to high to low.
Have ye any Piggs, Calves, or Colts,
Have ye any Lambs in your holts
To cut for the Stone
Here comes a cunning one.
Have ye any braches to ſpade,
Or e're a faire maide
That would be a Nun,
Come kiſſe me, 'tis done.
Harke how my merry borne doth blow,
Too high too low, too high too low.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: O excellent! two-pence a piece boyes, two-pence a piece:
Give the boys ſome drink there. Piper, wet your whiſtle.
Canſt tell me a way now, how to cut off my wives Con|cupiſcence?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I'le ſing ye a Song for't.

body.head: The Song.
body.l: And turn her again boy, again,
Then her diſeaſe no longer will raign.
And once a day ſwinge her again
If ſhe ſtand all theſe paines
Her diſeaſe no longer will reign.

sp.speaker: 1 Bo.
sp.l: More excellent, more excellent, ſweet Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: 2 Bo.
sp.l: Three-pence a peice, three-pence a peice.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Will you heare a Song how the Divel was gelded?

sp.speaker: 3 Bo.
sp.l: I, I, lets heare the Divell roare, Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: 1 Bo.
sp.l: Groats a piece, groats a piece, groats a piece,
There ſweet Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Will ye ſee any feates of activity,
Some ſleight of hand, leigerdemaine? hey paſſe,
Preſto, be gone there?

sp.speaker: 2 Bo.
sp.l: Sit downe Jugler.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Sirha, play you your art well; draw neer piper:
Looke you, my honeſt friends, you ſee my hands;
Plaine dealing is no Divel: lend me ſome money;
Twelve-pence a piece will ſerve.

sp.speaker: 1. 2. B.
sp.l: There, there.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I thanke you,
Thanke ye heartily: when ſhall I pay ye?

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, by'th maſſe this was a fine trick.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A merry ſleight toy: but now I'le ſhew your Worſhips
A tricke indeed.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Marke him well now my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here are three balls,
Theſe balls ſhall be three bullets,
One, two, and three: aſcentibus malentibus.
Preſto, be gone: they are vaniſh'd: faire play Gentlemen,
Now theſe three, like 3. bullets, from your three noſes
Will I plucke preſently: feare not, no harme boyes,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Ye pull too hard; ye pull too hard.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Stand faire then:

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Prig
sp.l: Come aloft bullets three, with a whim-wham:
Have ye their moneys?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Oh rare Jugler.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Oh admirable Jugler,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: One tricke more yet;
Hey, come aloft: ſa, ſa, flim, flum, taradumbis?
Eaſt, weſt, north, ſouth, now flye like Jacke with a bumbis.
Now all your money's gone: pray ſearch your pockets.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: He,

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: The Divell a penny's here.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: This was a rare tricke.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: But 'twould be a far rarer to reſtore it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'le doe ye that too: looke upon me earneſtly,
And move not any wayes your eyes from this place,
This button here: pow, whir, whiſs, ſhake your pockets

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: By'th maſſe 'tis here againe boyes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Reſt ye merry;
My firſt tricke has paid me.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: I, take it, take it,
And take ſome drinke too.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Not a drop now I thanke you;
Away, we are diſcoverd elſe. Exit.

sp.stage: Enter Gerrard like a blinde Aquavitae-man, and a boy ſinging the Song.
sp.l: BRing out your Cony-skins, faire maids to me,
And hold 'em faire that I may ſee;
Grey, blacke, and blew: for your ſmaller skins,
I'le give ye looking-glaſſes, pins.
And for your whole Coney, heer's ready ready money.
Come gentle Jone, do thou begin
With thy blacke, blacke, blacke Cony-skin.
And Mary then, and Jane will follow,
With their ſilver-hair'd skins, and their yellow.
The white Cony-skin, I will not lay by,
For though it be faint, tis faire to the eye,
The grey it is warme, but yet for my money,
Give me the bonny, bonny blacke Coney.
Come away faire maides, your skins will decay:
Come, and take money maids, put your ware away.
Cony-skins, Cony-skins, have ye any Cony-skins,
I have fine brace-lets, and fine ſilver pins.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Buy any brand wine, buy any brand wine?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Have ye any Cony-skins.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: My fine Canary-bird, ther's a cake for thy worſhip,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Come, fill, fill, fill, fill ſuddenly: let's ſee Sir,
What's this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A penny Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Fill till't be ſix-pence,
And there's my pig.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This is a counter Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: A counter? ſtay ye, what are theſe then?
O execrable Jugler! ô damn'd Jugler!
Look in your hoſe, hoa: this comes of looking forward.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Divell a Dunkirke! what a rogue's this Jugler,
This hey paſſe, repaſſe, h'as repaſt us ſweetly.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Doe ye call theſe tricks.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any ends of gold or ſilver.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: This fellow comes to mock us; gold or ſilver? cry copper.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Yes my good friend,
We have e'ne an end of all we have.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Ts well Sir,
You have the leſſe to care for: gold and ſilver, Exit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Have ye any old cloaks to ſel, have ye any old clokes to ſel. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Cloakes? looke about ye boyes: mine's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: A —juggle 'em?
— o' their Preſtoes: mine's gone too.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Here's mine yet.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Come, come, let's drink then: more brand wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: If e're I catch your Sow-gelder, by this hand I'le ſtrip him;
Were ever fooles ſo ferkt? we have two cloakes yet,
And all our caps; the Divell take the flincher.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, yaw, yaw.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Good do'n my honeſt fellows,
You are merry here I ſee.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: 'Tis all we have left Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What haſt thou? Aquavitae?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Fill out then,
And give theſe honeſt fellows round.

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: We thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: May I ſpeake a word in private to ye?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have a buſineſſe for you, honeſt friends,
If you dare lend your help, ſhall get you crownes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha?
Lead me a little nearer, boy.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: What is't Sir?
If it be any thing to purchaſe money,
Which is our want, command us.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: All, all, all Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You know the young ſpruce Merchant in Brugis.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Who? Maſter Goſwin?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That: he owes me money,
And here in towne there is no ſtirring of him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Say ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: This day, upon a ſure appointment,
He meets me a mile hence, by the Chaſe ſide
Under the row of Okes, do you know it?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Give 'em more drinke: there if you dare but venture
When I ſhall give the word to ſeize upon him,
Here's twenty pound.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: Beware the Jugler.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If he reſiſt, downe with him, have no mercy.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: I warrrant you: wee'l hamper him.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To diſcharge you,
I have a warrant here about me.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: Her's our warrant,
This carries fire i'the tayle.

sp.speaker: H●m.
sp.l: Away with me then,
The time draws on,
I muſt remove ſo inſolent a Suitor,
And if he be ſo rich, make him pay ranſome
Ere he ſee Bruges towres againe: thus wiſe men
Repaire the hurts they take by a diſgrace,
And piece the Lyons skyn with the Foxes caſe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad I have heard this ſport yet.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ther's for thy drink; come pay the houſe within boyes,
And looſe no time.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with all our haſt too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No winde blow faire yet? no returne of moneys?
Letters? nor any thing, to hold my hopes up?
Why then 'tis deſtin'd, that I fall, fall miſerably,
My credite I was built on, ſinking with me.
Thou boyſtrous North-wind, blowing my miſ-fortunes,
And froſting all my hopes to cakes of coldneſſe,
Yet ſtay thy fury: give the gentle South
Yet leave to court thoſe ſailes that bring me ſafety,
And you auſpicious fires, bright twins in heaven
Daunce on the ſhrowds: he blows ſtill, ſtubbornly,
And on his boyſtrous racke rides my ſad ruine;
There is no help, there can be now no comfort,
To morrow with the Sun-ſet ſets my credite.
Oh miſery! thou curſe of man, thou plague,
In the midſt all our ſtrength thou ſtrik'ſt us;
My vertuous Love is toſs'd too: all, what I have been,
No more hereafter to be ſeen then ſhadow;
To priſon now? well, yet ther's this hope left me,
I may ſinke fairely under this dayes venture
And ſo to morrow's croſs'd, and all thoſe curſes:
Yet manly I'le invite my fate, baſe fortune
Shall never ſay, ſhe has cut my throate in feare.
This is the place his challenge call'd me too,
And was a happy one at this time for me,
For let me fall before my foe i'the field,
And not at Bar, before my Creditors,
Ha's kept his word: now Sir, your ſwords tongue only
Loud as you dare, all other language—

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well Sir,
You ſhall not be long troubled: draw.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis done Sir,
And now have at ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Betray'd to Villains?
Slaves ye ſhall buy me bravely,
And thou baſe coward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now upon 'em bravely,
Conjure 'em ſoundly boyes.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Lay on ſtill,
Down with that Gentleman rogue, ſwinge him to ſirrup:
Retire Sir, and take breath: follow and take him,
Take all, 'tis lawfell prize.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We yield.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Downe with 'em
Into the wood, and rifile 'em, tew 'em, ſwinge 'em,
Knocke me their braines into their breeches. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What theſe men are I know not, nor for what cauſe
They ſhou●d thus thruſt themſelves into my danger,
Can I imagine. But ſure heavens hand was in't,
Nor why this coward knave ſhould deale ſo baſely
To eate me up with ſlaves: but heaven, I thanke thee,
I hope thou haſt reſerv'd me to an end
Fit for thy creature, and worthy of thine honour:
Would all my other dangers here had ſuffered,
With what a joyfull heart ſhould I goe home then?
Wher now, heaven knows, like him that waits his ſentēce
Or heares his paſſing bell; but ther's my hope ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bleſſing upon you Maſter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thanke ye; leave me,
For by my troth I have nothing now to give thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Indeed I do not aske Sir, only it grieves me
To ſee ye looke ſo ſad; now goodneſſe keepe ye
From troubles in your minde.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were troubled
What could thy comfort do? prethee Clauſe, leave me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good Maſter be not angry; for what I ſay
Is out of true love to ye..

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou lov'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good Mr. blame that love then, if I prove ſo ſawcy
To aske ye why ye are ſad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Moſt true, I am ſo,
And ſuch a ſadneſſe I have got will ſinke me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven ſhield it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith thou muſt looſe thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I had rather looſe my neck Sir: would I knew—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What would the knowledg do thee good, ſo miſerable,
Thou canſt not help thy ſelfe? when all my ways
Nor all the friends I have—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You do not know Sir,
What I can doe: cures ſometimes, for mens cares
Flow, where they leaſt expect 'em.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou wouldſt doe,
But fare-well Clauſe, and pray for thy poore Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will not leave ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I dare not leave ye,
And till ye beate me dead, I muſt not leave ye.
By what ye hold moſt pretious, by heavens goodneſſe,
As your faire youth may proſper, good Sir tell me:
My minde beleeves yet ſomething's in my power
May eaſe you of this trouble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell thee
For a hundred thouſand crownes upon my credit,
Taken up of Merchants to ſupply my traffiques,
The windes and weather envying of my fortune,
And no returne to help me off, yet ſhewing
To morrow, Clauſe, to morrow, which muſt come
In ſpron, thou ſhalt finde me poore, and broken.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I cannot blame your griefe Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now, what ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I ſay you ſhould not ſhrinck, for he that gave ye,
Can give you more; his power can bring ye off Sir,
When friends and all forſake ye, yet he ſees you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That's all my hope.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hope ſtill Sir, are you tide
Within the compaſſe of a day, good Maſter,
To pay this maſſe of money?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ev'n to morrow;
But why do I ſtand mocking of my miſery?
Is't not enough the floods, and friends forget me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Will no leſſe ſerve?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What if it would?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your patience,
I do not aske to mock ye: 'tis a great ſum,
A ſum for mighty men to ſtart, and ſtick at;
But not for honeſt: have ye no friends left ye,
None that have felt your bounty? worth this duty?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Duty? thou know'ſt it not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is a duty,
And as a duty, from thoſe men have felt ye,
Should be return'd againe: I have gain'd by ye,
A daily ●lmes theſe ſeven yearess you have ſhowr'd me,
Will half● ſupply your want.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou foole me?
Can'ſt thou worke miracles?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To ſave my Maſter,
I can worke this.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For doing good?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What power haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Enquire not:
So I can do it, to preſerve my Maſter;
Nay if it be three parts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O that I had it,
But good Clauſe, talke no more, I feele thy charity,
As thou has felt mine: but alas!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Diſtruſt not.
'Tis that that quenches ye: pull up your ſpirit,
Your good, your honeſt, and your noble ſpirit;
For if the fortunes often thouſand people
Can ſave ye, reſt aſſur'd; you have forgot Sir,
The good ye did, which was the power you gave me;
Ye ſhall now know the King of Beggars treaſure:
And let the windes blow as they pleaſe, the Seas roare,
Yet, here to morrow, you ſhall finde your harbour,
Here faile me not, for if I live I'le fit ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How faine I would believe thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: If I ly Maſter,
Believe no man hereafter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will trye thee,
But he knowes, that knowes all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Know me to morrow,
And if I know not how to cure ye, kill me;
So paſſe in peace, my beſt, my worthieſt Maſter. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus have I ſtolne away diſguiz'd from Hemskirck
To try theſe people, for my heart yet tells me
Some of theſe Beggars, are the men I looke for
Appearing like my ſelfe, they have no reaſon
(Though my intent is faire, my maine end honeſt)
But to avoyde me narrowly, that face too,
That womans face, how neere it is: ô may it
But prove the ſame, and fortune how I'le bleſſe thee;
Thus, ſure they cannot know me, or ſuſpect me,
If to my habit I but change my nature;
As I muſt do; this is the wood they live in,
A place fit for concealement: where, 'till fortune
Crowne me with that I ſeeke, I'le live amongſt 'em. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Gynks. and the reſt of the Boores.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Come bring 'em out, for here we ſit in juſtice:
Give to each one a cudgell, a good cudgell:
And now attend your ſentence, that you are rogues,
And miſcheivous baſe raſcalls, (ther's the point now)
I take it, is confeſſ'd.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Deny it if you dare knaves.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are Rogues Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To amplify the matter then rogues as ye are,
And lamb'd, ye ſhall be ere we leave ye.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And to the open handling of our juſtice,
Why did ye this upon the proper perſon
Of our good Maſter? were you drunk when you did it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes indeed were we.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: You ſhall be beaten ſober.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Was it for want you undertooke it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You ſhall be ſwing'd aboundantly.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And yet for all that,
You ſhall be poore rogues ſtill.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Has not the Gentleman,
Pray marke this point Brother Prig, that noble Gentleman
Releiv'd ye often, found ye meanes to live by,
By imploying ſome at Sea, ſome here; ſome there;
According to your callings?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Is not the man, an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A liberall Gentleman? and as ye are true raſcalls
Tell me but this, have ye not been drunk, and often,
At his charge?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Often, often.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ther's the point then,
They have caſt themſelves, brother Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A ſhrew'd point Brother.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Brother, proceed you now; the cauſe is open,
I am ſome what weary.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Can you do theſe things?
You moſt abhominable ſtincking Raſcalls,
You turnip-eating Rogues.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are truly ſorry.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Knock at your hard harts Rogues, and preſently
Give us a ſigne you feele compunction,
Every man up with's cudgell, and on his neighbour
Beſtow ſuch almes, 'till we ſhall ſay ſufficient,
For there your ſentence lyes without partiality;
Either of head, or hide, Rogues, without ſparing,
Or we ſhall take the paines to beat you dead elſe:
You ſhall know your doom.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: One, two, and three about it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: That fellow in the blew, has true compunction,
He beates his fellowes bravely, oh, well ſtruck boyes,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Up with that blew breech, now playes he the Divell,
So get ye home, drink ſmall beere, and be honeſt;
Call in the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do, bring him preſently,
His cauſe I'le heare my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Prig. With all due reverence,
We do reſigne Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now huffing Sir, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What's that to you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It ſhall be ere we part.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: My name is Hemskirk,
I follow the Earle, which you ſhall feele.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No threatning,
For we ſhall coole you Sir; why did'ſt thou baſely
Attempt the murder of the Merchant Go ſwin?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What power haſt thou to aske me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will know it.
Or flea thee till thy paine diſcover it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: He did me wrong, baſe wrong.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That cannot ſave ye,
Who ſent ye hither? and what further villanies
Have ye in hand?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Why would'ſt thou know? what profit,
If I had any private way, could riſe
Out of my knowledge, to do thee commodity?
Be ſorry for what thou haſt done, and make amends foole
I'le talke no further to thee: nor theſe raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tye him to that tree.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have told you whom I follow.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The Divell you ſhould do, by your villanies,
Now he that has the beſt way, wring it from him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I undertake it: turne him to the Sun boyes;
Give me a fine ſharpe ruſh, will ye confeſſe yet?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ye have rob'd me already, now you'le murder me

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Murder your noſe a little: does your head purge Sir?
To it againe, 'twill do ye good.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Oh,
I cannot tell you any thing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ther's maggots in your noſe, I'le fetch em out Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O my head breakes.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The beſt thing for the rhewme Sir,
That falls into your worſhips eyes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Speake then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know not what.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: It lyes in 's braine yet,
In lumps it lyes, I'le fetch it out the fineſt;
What pretty faces the foole makes? heigh!

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold,
Hold, and I'le tell ye all, looke in my doublet;
And there within the lining in a paper,
You ſhall finde all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go fetch that paper hither,
And let him looſe for this time.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Good ev'n my honeſt feiends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good ev'n good fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: May a poore huntſman, with a merry hart,
A voyce ſhall make the forreſt ring about him,
Get leave to live amongſt ye? true as ſteele, boyes?
That knowes all chaſes, and can watch all howres,
And with my quarter ſtaffe, though the Divell bid ſtand,
Deale ſuch an almes, ſhall make him roare again?
Prick ye the fearefull hare through croſſe wayes, ſheepe walkes
And force the crafty Reimald climb the quikſetts;
Rouſe ye the lofty Stag, and with my bell-horne,
Ring him a knell, that all the woods ſhall mourne him,
'Till in his funerall teares, he fall before me?
The Polcat, Marterne, and the rich skin'd Lucerne,
I know to chaſe, the Roe, the winde out-ſtripping
Iſgrin himſelfe, in all his bloody anger;
I can beate from the bay, and the wild Sounder
Single, and with my arm'd ſtaffe, turne the Boare,
Spight of his fomy tuſhes, and thus ſtrike him;
'Till he fall downe my feaſt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A goodly fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What mak'ſt thou here, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We accept thy fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Hemskirck, thou art not right I feare, I feare thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here is the paper: and as he ſaid we found it.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Give me it, I ſhall make a ſhift yet, old as I am
To finde your knavery: you are ſent here, Sirra
To diſcover certaine Gentlemen, a ſpy-knave
And if ye finde 'em, If not by perſwaſion
To bring 'em back, by poyſon to diſpatch 'em.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By poyſon, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here is an other, Hubert;
What is that Hubert Sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You may perceive there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I may perceive a villany and a ranke one,
Was he joyn'd partner of thy knavery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.
He had an honeſt end, would I have had ſo,
Which makes him ſcape ſuch cut throates.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So it ſeemes,
For here thou art commanded, when that Hubert
Has done his beſt and worthieſt ſervice, this way
To cut his throat, for here he's ſet downe dangerous.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This is moſt impious.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad we have found ye,
Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes? what are you the better;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You ſhall perceive Sir, ere you get your fredome:
Take him aſide, and friend, we take thee to us,
Into our company, thou dar'ſt be true unto us?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I, and obedient too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As you had bred me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then take our hand: thou art now a ſervant to us,
Welcom him all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Stand off, ſtand off: I'le do it,
We bid yee welcome three wayes; firſt for your perſon,
Which is a promiſing perſon, next for your quallity,
Which is a decent, and a gentle quality,
Laſt for the frequent meanes you have to feed us,
You can ſteale 'tis to be preſum'd.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, venſon,
Or if I want —

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis well you underſtand right,
And ſhall learne dayly: you can drink too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Soundly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And ye dare know a woman from a weathercock?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, if I handle her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now ſweare him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You are welcom Brother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcom, welcom, welcom, but who ſhall have the keeping
Of this fellow?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thank ye friends,
And I beſeech ye, if you dare but truſt me;
For if I have kept wilde doggs and beaſtes for wonder,
And made 'em tame too: give into my cuſtody
This roaring raſcall I ſhall hamper him,
With all his knacks and knaveryes, and I feare me
Diſcover yet a further villany in him;
O he ſmells ranck 'oth raſcall.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take him to thee,
But if he ſcape—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Let me be ev'n hang'd for him,
Roome Sir, I'le tye ye to my leaſh.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A way Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Be not ſo ſtubborne: I ſhall ſwindge ye ſoundly,
And ye play tricks with me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now ſweare him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I crowne thy nab, with a gag of benbouſe,
And ſtall thee by the ſalmon into the clowes,
To mand on the pad, and ſtrike all the cheates;
To mill from the Ruffmans, commiſion and ſtates,
Twang dell's, i' the ſtiromell, and let the Quire Cuffin:
And Herman Beck ſtrine, and trine to the Ruffin.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now interpret this unto him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I powre on thy pate a pot of good ale,
And by the Rogues oth a Rogue thee inſtall:
To beg on the way, to rob all thou meetes;
To ſteale from the hedge, both the ſhirt and the ſheetes:
And lye with thy wench in the ſtraw till ſhe twang,
Let the Conſtable, Iuſtice, and Divell go hang.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So, now come in,
But ever have an eye Sir, to your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: He muſt blinde both mine eyes, if he get from me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go, get ſome victualls, and ſome drink, ſome good drink
For this day wee'le keep holly to good fortune,
Come and be frollick with us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: ye are a ſtanger. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Indeed yae'r welcom: I have hard your ſcape,
And therefore give her leave, that onely loves you;
(Truely and dearely loves ye) give her joy leave,
To bid ye welcom: what'iſt makes you ſad man?
Why do you looke ſo wilde? is 't I offend ye?
Be ſhrew my heart, not willingly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is't the delay of that ye' long have look'd for,
A happy marriage? now I come to urge it:
Now when ye pleaſe to finiſh it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No newes yet?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you heare Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Flo..
sp.l: Have I liv'd,
In all the happineſſe fortune could ſeat me,
In all mens faire opinions?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have provided
A Prieſt, that's ready for us.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And can the Divell,
In one ten dayes, that Divell chance devour me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Wee'le fly to what place you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: No ſtar proſperous?
All at a ſwoope?

sp.speaker: Ber:
sp.l: You do not love me Goſwin?
You will not looke upon me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can mens prayers
Shot up to heaven, with ſuch a zeale as mine are,
Fall back like lazy miſts, and never proſper?
Geyves, I muſt weare, and cold muſt be my comfort;
Darkneſſe, and want of meat; alas ſhe weepes too,
Which is the top of all my ſorrowes, Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, you will not know me; my poore beauty,
Which has been worth your eyes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The time growes on ſtill:
And like a tumbling wave, I ſee my ruine,
Come rolling over me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye know me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thouſand crownes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye love me?
Tell me but how I have deſerv'd your ſlighting.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thouſand crownes?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Farewell diſſembler.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Of which I have ſcarce ten: ô how it ſtarts me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And may the next you love, hearing my ruine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I had forgot my ſelfe, ô my beſt Gertred,
Crowne of my joyes, and comforts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: ſweet what ayle ye?
I thought you had been vext with me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My minde wench,
My minde o're flow'd with ſorrow, ſunck my memory.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Am I not worthy of the knowledge of it?
And cannot I as well affect your ſorrowes,
As your delights? you love no other woman?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You have no ſhips loſt lately?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I hope you have ſpilt no blood: whoſe innocence
May lay this on your conſcience.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Cleare, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why ſhould you be thus then?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good Jertred, aske not,
Ev'n By the love you beare me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am obedient.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Go in my faire; I will not be long from ye,
Nor long I feare me with thee, At my returne
Deſpiſe me as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The good gods guide ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now for my ſelfe which is the leaſt I hope for,
And when that failes, for mans worſt fortune, pitty. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: WHy Gentlemen, 'tis but a week more I intreat you
But 7. ſhort daies, I am not runnig from ye,
Nor, if you give me patience, is it poſſible
All my adventures faile; you have ſhips abroad,
Endure the beating both of winde, or weather:
I am ſure 'twould vex your hearts, to be proteſted
Ye are all faire Merchants,

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Yes, and muſt have faire play;
There is no lying here elſe, one howres failing
Failes us of all our friends, of all our credits:
For my part I would ſtay; but my wants tell me,
I muſt wrong others in't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No mercy in ye?

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis fooliſh to depend on others mercy:
Keepe your ſelfe right, and even, out your cloth Sir,
According to your calling: you have liv'd here
In Lordlike prodigality; high, and open,
And now ye finde what 'tis: the liberall ſpending
The ſummer of your youth, which you ſhould gleane in,
And like the labouring Ant, make uſe and gaine of,
Has brought this bitter ſtormy winter on ye,
And now you cry.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Alas before your poverty,
We were no men, of no marke, no endeavour;
You ſtood alone, tooke up all trade, all buſineſs,
Running through your hands, ſcarce a ſayle at Sea,
But loaden with your goods: we poore weak pedlers,
When by your leave, and much intreaty to it:
We could have ſtoage for a little cloth,
Or a few wines, put of and thanke your worſhip
Lord, how the world's chang'd with ye? now I hope Sir,
We ſhall have ſea-roome

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is my miſery,
Become my ſcorne too? have ye no humanity,
No part of men left? are all the bountyes in me
To you, and to the Towne; turn'd my reproaches?

sp.speaker: 4. Mer.
sp.l: Well, get your monyes ready: 'tis but 2. howres
We ſhall proteſt ye elſe, and ſodainly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But two dayes.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Not an howre, ye know the hazard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How ſoone my light's put out: hard harted Bruges;
Within thy walls, may never honeſt Merchant
Venture his fortunes more: ô my poore wench too;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good fortune Maſter.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Thou miſtak'ſt me Clauſe,
I am not worth thy bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Stil a ſad man?
sp.stage: Enter Higgen. and Prig. like Porter.
sp.l: No beliefe gentle Maſter? come bring it in then,
And now believe your Beadeſman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this certaine?
Or do'ſt thou work upon my troubled ſence?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis gold Sir,
Take it and try it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Certainely 'tis treaſure,
Can there be yet this bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ceaſe your wonder,
You ſhall not ſinke, for nev'r a ſowſt Flap-dragon:
For nere a pickell'd pilcher of 'em all Sir,
'Tis there your full ſumm, a hundred thouſand crownes,
And good ſweet Maſter, now Be merry: pay 'em
Pay the poore pelting knaves, that know no goodneſſe:
And cheere your heart up handſomely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good Clauſe,
How cam'ſt thou by this mighty ſumm? if naughtily
I muſt not take it of thee, 'twill undo me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Feare not: you have it by as honeſt meanes
As though your father gave it: Sir, you know not
To what a maſſe, the little we get dayly,
Mounts in ſeven yeares; we beg it for heavens charity,
And to the ſame good, we are bound to render it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What great ſecurity?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with that Sir,
Were not ye more then all the men in Bruges;
And all the money in my thoughts—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But good Clauſe,
I may dye preſently.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Then this dyes with ye-
Pay when you can good Maſter, I'le no parchments,
Onely this charity I ſhall intreat ye,
Leave me this Ring.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas, it is to poore Clauſe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis all I aske, and this with all, that when
I ſhall deliver this back, you ſhall grant me
Freely one poore petition.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There I confeſſe it,
And may my faith forſake mee when I ſhun it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away, your time drawes on. Take up the money
And follow this young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Farewell Clauſe,
And may thy honeſt memory live ever.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe ye and ſtill keep ye, farewell Maſter.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have lockt my youth up cloſe enough for gadding
In an olde tree, and ſet watch over him.
Now for my Love, for ſure this wench muſt be ſhe,
She follows me; Come hither, pretty Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac,
sp.l: No, no, you'l kiſſe,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: So I will.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Y'ded law?
How will ye kiſſe me, pray you?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus: ſoft as my loves lips.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What's your Fathers name?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He's gone to heaven.

sp.speaker: Hub.
