sp.l: Is it not Gerrard, ſweet?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I'le ſtay no longer,
My mother's an olde woman, and my Brother
Was drown'd at ſea, with catching Cockles. O love:
O how my heart melts in me: how thou fir'ſt me!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis certain ſhe: pray let me ſee your hand, ſweet,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, no, you'l bite it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sure I ſhould know that Gymmall;

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine he: I had forgot my ring too.
O Hubert, Hubert.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ha? me-thought ſhe nam'd me—
Doe you know me, Chicke?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No indeed, I never ſaw ye,
But me-thinks you kiſſe finely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Kiſſe againe then;
By heaven 'tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O what a joy he brings me.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are not Minche?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes pretty Gentleman,
And I muſt be married to morrow to a Capper.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Muſt ye my ſweet, and doe's the Capper love ye?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, yes, he'l give me pye, & look in mine eys thus:
Tis he: 'tis my deare Love; ô bleſt fortune.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How fain ſhe would conceal her ſelfe? yet ſhew it,
Will ye love me, and leave that man? I'le ſerve.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O I ſhall looſe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I'le waite upon ye,
And make ye dainty Noſe-gayes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And where will ye ſticke 'em?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Here in boſome, and make a crown of Lillies
For your faire head.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And will ye love me, deed-law?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Call me to morrow then,
And we'l have brave chear, and goe to Church together:
Give you good ev'n Sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: But one word faire Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I muſt be gone a milking.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye ſhall preſently.
Did you never heare of a young Maid called Jaculine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am diſcovered: hark in your eare, I'le tell ye;
You muſt not know me: kiſſe and be conſtant ever.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Heaven curſe me elſe: tis ſhe, and now I am certain
They are all here: now for my other project.— Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Floriz. 4. Merchants, Higgen, and Prig.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Nay if it would do you courteſy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None at all Sir;
Take it 'tis yours: ther's your ten thouſand for ye,
Give in my Bills: your ſixteene.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Pray be pleas'd Sir,
To make a further uſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: What I have Sir,
You may command; pray let me be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Put your hatts on: I care not for your courtiſies,
They are moſt untimely don, and no truth in 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I have a frought of pepper.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rot your pepper,
Shall I truſt you againe? ther's your ſeven thouſand.

sp.speaker: 4. Mer.
sp.l: Or if you want fine ſuger, 'tis but ſending.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, I can ſend to Barbary, thoſe people
That never yet knew faith, have nobler freedoms:
Theſe carry to Vanlock, and take my Bills in
To Peter Zuten theſe: bring back my Iewells;
Why are theſe peices?

sp.speaker: Saylor.
sp.l: Health to the noble Merchant,
The Suſan is return'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Well, and rich Sir,
And now put in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven thou haſt heard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: The brave Rebecca too: bound from the ſtraights,
With the next tide is ready to put after.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What newes o'th' fly-boate?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: If this winde hold till midnight,
She will be here, and wealthy, ſcap't fairely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How, pre'thee Saylor?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Thus Sir, ſhe had fight
Seven howers together, with ſix Turkiſh Gallyes,
And ſhe fought bravely: but at length was borded:
And over lai'd with ſtrength: when preſently
Comes boring up the winde Captaine Van-noke,
That valiant Gentleman, you redeem'd from priſon;
He knew the Boate, ſet in: and fought it bravely:
Beate all the Gallies off; ſunk three, redeem'd her,
And as a ſervice to ye, ſent her home Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An honeſt noble Captaine, and a thankfull;
Ther's for thy new's: go drink the Merchants health, Saylor

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: I thanke your bounty, and I'le do it to a doyt, Sir,

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: What miracles are powr'd upon this fellow?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This ye are I hope my friends, I ſhall ſcape priſon,
For all your cares to catch me.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer
sp.l: You may pleaſe Sir
To think of your poor ſervants in diſpleaſure,
Whoſe all they have, goods, monyes, are at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thank you,
When I have need of you I ſhall forget you:
You are paid I hope.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We joy in your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Come Sir, come take your eaſe you muſt go home
With mee, yonder is one weepes and howles.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas how does ſhe?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: She will be better ſoone I hope.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why ſoone ſir?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Why when you have her in your armes, this night,
My boy ſhe is thy wife

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With all my hart I take her.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: We have prepar'd, all thy friends will be there,
And all my Roomes ſhall ſmoake to ſee the revell;
Thou haſt been wrong'd and no more ſhall my ſeruice,
Waite on the knaue her Vncle, I have hard all,
All his baites for my Boy, but thou ſhalt have her;
Haſt thou diſpatch't thy buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Moſt.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: By the maſſe Boy,
Thou tumbleſt now in wealth, and I joy in it,
Thou art the beſt Boy, that Bruges ever nouriſh'd
Thou haſt been ſad, I'le cheere thee up with Sack,
And when thou art luſty I'le fling thee to thy Miſtris.
Shee'l hug thee, ſirha.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I long to ſee it,
I had forgot you: ther's for, you my friends:
You had but heavy burthens, commend my love
To my beſt love, all the love I have
To honeſt Clauſe, ſhortly I will thanke him better. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: By the maſſe a royall Merchant,
Gold by the handfull, here will be ſport, ſoone Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It partly ſeemes ſo, and here will I be in a trice.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And I boy,
Away a pace we are look'd for.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Oh theſe bak'd meates,
Me thinkes I ſmell them hither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thy mouth waters. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I Muſt not,

sp.speaker: Hemſ.
sp.l: Why? 'tis in thy power to do it, and in mine
To reward thee to thy wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I dare not, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Gentle Huntſman,
Though thou haſt kept me hard: though in thy duty,
Which is requir'd to do it, th' haſt uſed me ſtubbornly;
I can forgive thee freely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You the Earles ſervant.

sp.speaker: Hemſ.
sp.l: I ſweare I am neare as his owne thoughts to him;
Able to doe thee—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come, come, leave your prating.

sp.speaker: Hemſ.
sp.l: If thou dar'ſt but try.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I thanke you hartily, you will be
The firſt man that will hang me, a ſweet recompence,
I could do, but I do not ſay I will,
To any honeſt fellow that would thinke on't:
And be a benefactor.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If it be not recompenc'd, and to thy owne deſires,
If within theſe ten dayes I do not make thee—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What, a falſe knave?

sp.speaker: Hemſ.
sp.l: Prethee, prethee conceive me rightly, any thing
Of profit or of place that may advance thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Why what a Gooſecap would'ſt thou make me,
Do not I know that men in miſery will promiſe
Any thing, more then their lives can reach at?

sp.speaker: Hemſ.
sp.l: Beleeve me Huntſman,
There ſhall not one ſhort ſillable
That comes from me, paſſe
Without it's full performance.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Say you ſo Sir?
Have ye e're a good place for my quality.

sp.speaker: H●m.
sp.l: A thouſand Chaſes, Forreſts, Parks: I'le make thee
Chiefe ranger over all the games.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Preſently.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This may provoke me: and yet to prove a knave too.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis to prove honeſt: 'tis to do good ſervice,
Service for him thou art ſworn to, for thy Prince,
Then for thy ſelfe that good; what fool would live here,
Poore, and in miſery, ſubject to all dangers,
Law, and lewd people can inflict, when bravely
And to himſelfe he may be law, and credit?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Shall I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As that thou holdſt moſt holy;

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye may play tricks.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Then let me never live more.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Then you ſhall ſee Sir, I will do a ſervice
That ſhall deſerve indeed.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſaid, huntſ-man,
And thou ſhalt be well thought of.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I will do it: 'tis not your letting free, for that's meer nothing,
But ſuch a ſervice, if the Earl be noble,
He ſhall for ever love me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What is't huntſ-man?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do you know any of theſe people live here?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are a foole then: here be thoſe to have 'em,
I know the Earl ſo well, would make him caper.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Any of the old Lords that rebel'd?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Peace, all,
I know 'em every one, and can betray 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: But wilt thou doe this ſervice?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If you'l keep
Your faith, and free word to me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Wilt thou ſwear me?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, no, I will beleeve ye: more then that too,
Here's the right heire.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O honeſt, honeſt huntſ-man!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Now, how to get theſe Gallants, ther's the matter,
You will be conſtant, 'tis no work for me elſe.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Will the Sun ſhine agen?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: The way to get 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Propound it, and it ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No ſleight;
(For they are Devilliſh crafty, it concerns 'em,)
Nor reconcilement, (for they dare not truſt neither)
Muſt doe this tricke.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I, that muſt doe it.
And with the perſon of the Earl himſelfe,
Authority (and mighty) muſt come on 'em:
Or elſe in vaine: and thus I would have ye do it.
To morrow-night be here: a hundred men will bear 'em,
(So he be there, for he's both wiſe and valiant)
And with his terrour will ſtrike dead their forces,
The houre be twelve a clock, now for a guide
To draw ye without danger on theſe perſons,
The woods being thicke, and hard to hit, my ſelfe
With ſome few with me, made unto our purpoſe,
Beyond the wood, upon the plain, will wait ye
By the great Oke.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know it: keep thy faith huntſ-man,
And ſuch a ſhowr of wealth—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I warrant ye:
Miſſe nothing that I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell;
You have your liberty, now uſe it wiſely;
And keep your houre, goe cloſer about the wood there,
For feare they ſpy you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And bring no noyſe with ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: All ſhall be done to'th purpoſe: farewel huntſ-mā. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Gerrard, Higgen, Prig, Ginks, Snap, Ferret.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now, what's the news in towne?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: No news, but joy Sir;
Every man wooing of the noble Merchant,
Who has his hearty commendations to ye.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Yes, this is news, this night he's to be married.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: By'th maſſe that's true, he marryes Vandoncks daughter
The dainty black-ey'd bell.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I would my clapper
Hung in his baldricke, what a peale could I ring?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Marryed?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: 'Tis very true Sir, ô the pyes,
The piping-hot mince-pyes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O the Plum-pottage.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: For one leg of a gooſe now would I ventura limb boys,
I love a fat gooſe, as I love allegiance,
And—upon the Boors, too well they know it,
And therefore ſtarve their powltry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To be married
To Vandonks daughter?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: O this pretious Merchant:
What ſport he will haue? but hark ye brother Prig,
Shall we do nothing in the fore-ſaid wedding?
Ther's money to be got, and meate I take it,
What thinke ye of a moriſe?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: No, by no meanes,
That goes no further then the ſtreet, there leaves us,
Now we muſt think of ſomething that muſt draw us
Into the bowels of it, into'th buttery,
Into the Kitchin, into the Cellar, ſomething
That that old drunken Burgo-maſter loves,
What think ye of a waſſell?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I think worthily.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And very fit it ſhould be, thou, and Ferret,
And Ginks to ſing the Song: I for the ſtructure,
Which is the bowle.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Which muſt be up-ſey Engliſh,
Strong, luſty London beer; let's think more of it,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: He muſt not marry.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By your leave in private,
One word Sir, with ye; Gerrard: do not ſtart me,
I know ye, and he knows ye, that beſt loves ye:
Hubert ſpeakes to ye, and you muſt be Gerrard,
The time invites you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Make no ſhow then,
I am glad to ſee you Sir; and I am Gerrard.
How ſtands affaires?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Faire, if ye dare now follow,
Hemskirke I have let goe, and theſe my cauſes,
I'le tell ye privately, and how I have wrought him,
And then to prove me honeſt to my friends,
Looke upon theſe directions; you have ſeen his.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then will I ſpeak a ſpeech, and a brave ſpeech
In praiſe of Merchants, where's the Ape

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: —Take him,
A gowty Beare-ward ſtole him the other day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May his Beares worry him, that Ape had paid it,
What dainty tricks? —o' that whorſon Bear-ward:
In his french doublet, with his baſter'd bullions,
In a long ſtock ty'd up; o how daintily
Would I have made him waite, and change a trencher,
Cary a cup of wine? ten thouſand ſtinks
Waite on thy mangy ſoule, thou lowzy Bear-ward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis paſſing well, I both beleeve and joy in't
And will be ready; keepe you here the meane while,
And keepe this in, I muſt a while forſake ye,
Upon mine anger no man ſtir, this two houres.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not to the wedding ſir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not any whither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The wedding muſt be ſeene ſir; we want meat too,
VVe be monſtrous out of meat.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Shall it be ſpoken,
Fatt Capon ſhak't their tailes at's in defiance?
And turkey toombs ſuch honorable monuments,
Shall piggs, ſir, that the Perſons ſelfe would envy,
And deintie Ducks?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not a word more, obey me. Exit Ger.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: VVhy then come dolefull death, this is flat tyrany
And by this hand —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ile goe ſleepe upon't. Exit Hig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nay, and there be a wedding, and we wanting
Farewell our happie daies: we doe obey ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: VVell met ſir, you are for this luſty wedding.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I am ſo, ſo are you I take it.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Yes,
And it much glads me, that to doe him ſervice
Who is the honour of our trade, and luſter,
VVe meet thus happily.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: He's a noble fellow,
And well becomes a bride of ſuch a beauty.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: She is paſſing faire indeed, long may their loves
Continue like their youths, in ſpring of ſweetneſſe,
All the young Merchants will be here
No doubt on't,
For he that comes not to attend this wedding
The curſe of a moſt blind one fall upon him,
A lowd wife, and a lazie: here's Vanlock.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: VVell overtaken gentlemen: ſave ye.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: The ſame to you ſir; ſave ye faire Miſtris Francis,
I would this happie night might make you bluſh too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: She dreames a pace,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That's but a drowſie fortune.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Nay take us with ye too; we come to that end,
I am ſure ye are for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Hand and heart man:
And what their feet can doe, I could have tript it
Before this whorſon gout

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bleſſe ye Maſters.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Clauſe? how now Clauſe; thou art come to ſee thy Maſter,
(And a good maſter he is to all poore people)
In all his joy, tis honeſtly don of thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Long may hee live ſir, but my buſineſſe now is
If you would plaſe to doe it, and to him too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: He's heere himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Stand at the doore my friends?
I pray walke in: welcome faire Miſtris Francis,
See what the houſe affords, ther's a young Lady
VVill bid you welcome,

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: VVe joy your happineſſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I hope It will be ſo: Clauſe nobly welcome,
My honeſt, my beſt friend, I have been carefull
To ſee thy monys—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, that brought not me,
Do you know this Ring againe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou hadſt it of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And do you well remēber yet, the boone you gave me
Upon returne of this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, and I grant it,
Be it what it will: aske what thou can'ſt, I'le do it;
Within my power.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ye are not married yet

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Faith I ſhall aske you that that will diſturb ye,
But I muſt put ye to your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do,
And if I faint and flinch in't—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Well ſaid Maſter,
And yet it grieves me too: and yet it muſt be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prethee diſtruſt me not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You muſt not marry,
That's part of the power you gave me: which to make up,
You muſt preſently depart, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Not marry Clauſe?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not if you keep your promiſe,
And give me power to aske.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pre'thee thinke better,
I will obey, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I have thought the beſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Give me thy reaſon, do'ſt thou feare her honeſty?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Chaſte as the yee, for any thing I know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why ſhould'ſt thou light on that then? to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I muſt not now diſcover.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Muſt not marry?
Shall I breake now when my poore hart is pawn'd?
When all the preparation?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Come, 'tis not that thou would'ſt: thou doſt but fright me

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Upon my ſoule it is Sir, and I binde ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Clauſe, can'ſt thou be ſo cruell?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You may breake Sir,
But never more in my thoughts, appeare honeſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Did'ſt ever ſee her?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She is ſuch a thing,
O Clauſe, ſhe is ſuch a wonder, ſuch a mirror,
For beauty, and faire vertue, Europe has not:
Why haſt thou made me happy, to undo me?
But looke upon her; then if thy heart relent not,
I'le quit her preſently, who waites there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Bid my faire love come hither, and the company,
Pre'thee be good unto me; take a mans hart
And looke upon her truly: take a friends hart
And feele what miſery muſt follow this,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take you a noble hart and keep your promiſe;
I forſooke all I had, to make you happy.
sp.stage: Enter Bertha. Van-donck, and the reſt Merchants.
sp.l: Can that thing call'd a woman, ſtop your goodneſſe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Looke there ſhe is, deale with me as thou wilt now
Did'ſt ever ſee a fayrer?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She is moſt goodly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ayles my love?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Did'ſt thou ever,
By the faire light of heaven, behold a ſweeter?
O that thou knew'ſt but love, or ever felt him,
Looke well, looke narrowly upon her beauties.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.p: Sure h'as ſome ſtrange deſigne in hand, he ſtarts ſo.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: This Beggar has a ſtrong power over his plea|ſure

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: View all her body.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis exact and excellent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is ſhe a thing then to be loſt thus lightly?
Her mind is ten times ſweeter, ten times nobler,
And but to heare her ſpeak, a Paradiſe,
And ſuch a love ſhe beares to me, a chaſte love,
A vertuous, faire, and fruitfull love: 'tis now too
I am ready to enjoy it; the Prieſt ready: Clauſe,
To ſay the holy words ſhall make us happy,
This is a cruelty beyond mans ſtudy,
All theſe are ready, all our joyes are ready,
And all the expectation of our friends,
Twill be her death to do it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let her dye then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou canſt not: 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It muſt be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twill kil me too, 'twil murder me: by heaven Clauſ
I'le give thee halfe I have; come thou ſhalt ſave me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then you muſt goe with me: I can ſtay no longer
If ye be true, and noble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Hard heart, I'le follow:
Pray ye all goe in againe, and pray be merry,
I have a weighty buſineſſe, give my cloake there.
Concerns my life, and ſtate; make no enquiry,
This preſent houre befaln me: with the ſooneſt
I ſhall be here againe: nay pray goe in Sir,
And take them with you, tis but a night loſt, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, come in, we will not looſe our meat yet,
Nor our good mirth, he cannot ſtay long from her
I am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will not ſtay; beleeve Sir. Exit.
Gertrud, a word with you;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why is this ſtop, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have no more time left me, but to kiſſe thee,
And tell thee this, I am ever thine: farewell wench. Exit.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: And is that all your ceremony? Is this a wedding?
Are all my hopes and prayers turnd to nothing?
Well, I will ſay no more, nor ſigh, nor ſorrow; oh me,
Till to thy face I prove thee falſe. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: LEad, if thou thinkſt we are right: why doſt thou make
Theſe often ſtands? thou ſaidſt thou knewſt the way

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Fsar nothing, I doe know it: would twere home|ward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Wrought from me, by a Beggar? at the time
That moſt ſhould tye him? Tis ſome other Love
That hath a more command on his affections,
And he that fetcht him, a diſguiſed Agent,
Not what he perſonated; for his faſhion
Was more familiar with him, and more powerfull
Then one that ask'd an almes: I muſt finde out
One, if not both: kind darkneſſe be my ſhrowd
And cover loves too curious ſearch in me,
For yet, ſuſpition, I would not name thee.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Miſtris, it grows ſome-what pretty and dark.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Nay, nothing; do not thinke I am afraid,
Although perhaps you are.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am not, forward.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Sure but you are: give me your hand, fear nothing.
There's one leg in the wood, do not pull backward:
What a ſweate one on's are in, you or I?
Pray God it do not prove the plague; yet ſure
It has infected me; for I ſweat too,
It runs out at my knees, feele, feele, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ailes the fellow?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Hark, hark I beſech you,
Doe you heare nothing?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Lyſt: a wilde hog,
He grunts: now 'tis a beare: this wood is full of 'em,
And now, a wolfe Miſtris, a wolfe a wolfe,
It is the howling of a wolfe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The braying of an aſſe, is it not.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Oh, now one has me;
Oh, my left ham, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Looke to your ſhankes,
Your breech is ſafe enough, the wolfe's a Fern-brake.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: But ſee, ſee, ſee. There is a ſerpent in it,
It has eyes as broad as platters; it ſpits fire;
Now it creeps towards us, help me to ſay my prayers:
It hath ſwallowed me almoſt, my breath is ſtopt,
I cannot ſpeake; do I ſpeake Miſtris? tell me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why, thou timerous Sot, canſt thou perceive
Any thing i'the buſh, but a poore glo-worme?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: It may be tis but a glo-worm now, but 'twill
Grow to a fire-drake preſently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come thou from it:
I have a pretious guide of you; and a courteous
That gives me leave to lead my ſelfe the way thus.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: It thunders, you heare that now.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I heare one hollow.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: 'Tis thunder, thunder:
See, a flaſh of Lightning:
Are you not blaſted Miſtris? pull your maske off,
It has plaid the barber with me here: I have loſt
My beard, my beard, pray God you be not ſhaven,
'Twill ſpoile your marriage Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ſtrange wonders,
Feare fancies in a Coward?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Now, the earth opens.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Prethee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Will you on then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Both love and jealouſie have made me bold,
Where my fate leads me, I muſt goe. Ex●t.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: God be with you then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: It was the fellow ſure, he that ſhould guide me,
The huntſ-man that did hollow us.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Beſt make a ſtand
And liſten to his next: ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Miſtris, I am taken.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Miſtris? look forth ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: What are you ſirha?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Truly all is left
Of a poore Boore, by day-light, by night no body,
You might have ſpar'd your drum, and guns, & pikes too
For I am none that will ſtand out Sir, I.
You may take me in with a walking ſticke
Euen when you pleaſe, and hold me with a pack-threed.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What woman was't you call'd to.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: VVoman? none Sir.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: None? did you not name Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Yes, but ſhee's
No woman yet! ſhe ſhould have been this night,
But that a Beggar ſtole away her Bridegroome,
VVhom we were going to make hue and cry after;
I tell you true Sir, ſhe ſhould ha'bin maried to day,
And was the Bride, and all; but in came Clauſe,
The old lame Beggar, and whips up M^r. Goſwin;
Under his arme; away with him as a Kite,
Or an old Fox, would ſwoope a way a goſling.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe, 'tis ſhe, 'tis ſhe, Niece?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: She Sir,
This was a noble entrance to your fortune,
That being on the point thus to be married:
Upon her venture here: you ſhould ſurpriſe her.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: I begin Hemskirck, to believe my fate,
Works to my ends.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and this adds truſt,
Unto the fellow our guide, who aſſur'd me Floris,
Liv'd in ſome Merchants ſhop, as Gerrard did:
I' the old beggars, and that he would uſe
Him for the traine, to call the other forth,
All which we finde is done—That's he againe— Holla againe

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Good we ſent out to meet him.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Heer's the Oke.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I am miſerably loſt, thus falne
Into my vncles hands from all my hopes,
Can I not thinke away my ſelfe and dye?
O I am miſerably loſt; thus fallen
Into my Uncles hands, from all my hopes:
No matter now, where thou be falſe or no,
Goſwin, whether thou love an other better;
Or me alone; or where thou keep thy vow,
And word, or that thou come, or ſtay: for I
To thee from henceforth, muſt be ever abſent,
And thou to me: no more ſhall we come neere,
To tell our ſelves, how bright each other eyes were,
How ſoft our language, and how ſweet our kiſſes,
Whil'ſt we made one our food, th' other our feaſt,
Not mix our ſoules by ſight, or by a letter
Hereafter, but as ſmall relation have,
As two new gon to in habiting a grave:
Can I not thinke away my ſelfe and dye?

div.stage: Enter Hubert. Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Snap. Gincks. like Boores.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I like your habits well: they are ſafe, ſtand cloſe

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: But what's the action we are for now? ha?
Robbing a Ripper of his fiſh?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or taking,
A poultrer priſoner, without ranſome, Bullyes?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or cutting off a convoy of butter?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Or ſurpriſing a Boores ken, for granting cheates?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or cackling cheates?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or mergery-praters, Rogers,
And Tibs o'th the Buttry?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O' I could drive a Regiment
Of geeſe afore me, ſuch a night as this
Ten leagues with my hatt, and ſtaff, and not a hiſſe
Heard, or a wing of my troopes diſordered.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Tell us,
If it be milling of a lag of duds,
The fetching of a back of clothes or ſo;
We are horribly out of linnen.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Let me alone for any Farmers dog,
If you have a minde to the cheeſe-loft: 'tis but thus:
And he is a ſilenc'd Maſtiff, during pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Would it would pleaſe you to be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Mum.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A friend, the Huntſman.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: O 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have kept touch Sir, which is the Earle of theſe?
Will ye know a man now?

sp.speaker: Hems,
sp.l: This my Lord's the friend,
Hath undertooke the ſervice.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If 't be worth
His Lordſhips thanks anon, when 'tis done
Lording, I'le looke for't, a rude woodman,
I know how to pitch my toyles, drive in my game:
And I have don't, both Floriz and his Father
Old Gerrard, with Lord Arnold of Benthuiſen,
Cozen, and Jaqueline, young Floris Siſter;
I haue 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt too much, too happy,
To carry faith with it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I can bring you
Where you ſhall ſee, and finde 'em.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We will double,
What ever Hemskirck then hath promis'd thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And I'le deſerve it treble; what horſe ha you?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: A hundred.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: That's well: ready to take
Upon ſurpriſe of 'em?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Devide then,
Your force into five Squadrous; for there are
So many out lets, wayes, thorough the wood,
That iſſue from the place: where they are lodg'd;
Five ſeverall wayes, of all which paſſages
We muſt poſſes our ſelves, to round 'em in,
For by one ſtarting hole, they'll all eſcape elſe;
I and 4. Boores here, to me will be guides,
The Squadron, where you are, my ſelfe will lead:
And that they may be more ſecure, I'le uſe
My wonted whoopes, and hollowes, as I were
A hunting for 'em; which will make them reſt,
Careles of any noyſe, and be a direction
To the other guides, how we approch 'em ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: 'Tis orderd well, and reliſheth the Souldier,
Make the diviſion Hemskirck: you are my charge
Faire one, I'le looke to you.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Shall no body need
To looke to me? I'le looke unto my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis but this, remember.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Say 'tis don boy. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By this time Sir I hope you want no reaſons
Why I broke off your marriage, for though I
Should as a Subject ſtudy you my Prince
In things indifferent, it will not therefore
Diſcredit you, to acknowledge me your Father,
By harkning to my neceſſary counſells.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Acknowledge you my Father? Sir I do,
And may impiety, conſpiring with
My other Sinnes, ſinck me, and ſodainly
When I forget to pay you a Sonnes duty
In my obedience, and that help'd forth
With all the cheerefullneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I pray you riſe,
And may thoſe powers that ſee and love this in you,
Reward you for it: Taught by your example
Having receiv'd the rights due to a Father,
I tender you th' allegance of a Subject:
Which as my Prince accept of.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Kneele to me?
May mountaines firſt fall down beneath their valleys,
And fire no more mount upwards, when I ſuffer
An act in nature ſo prepoſterous;
I mu●t o'recome in this, in all things elſe
The victory be yours: could you here read me,
You ſhould perceive how all my faculties
Triumph in my bleſt fate, to be found yours;
I am your ſon, your ſon Sir, and am prouder
To be ſo, to the Father, to ſuch goodneſſe
(Which heaven be pleas'd, I may inherit from you)
Then I ſhall ever of thoſe ſpecious titles
That plead for my ſucceſſion in the Earldome
(Did I poſſeſſe it now) left by my mother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I do beleeve it: but—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O my lov'd Father,
Before I knew you were ſo, by inſtinct,
Nature had taught me, to look on your wants,
Not as a ſtrangers: and I know not how,
What you call'd charity, I thought the payment
Of ſome religious debt, nature ſtood bound for;
And laſt of all, when your magnificent bounty
In my low ebb of fortune, had brought in
A flood of bleſſings, though my threatning wants
And feare of their effects, ſtill kept me ſtupid,
I ſoone found out, it was no common pitty
That lead you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thinke of this hereafter
When we with joy may call it to remembrance,
There will be a time, more opportune, then now
To end your ſtory, with all circumſtances,
I add this only: when we fled from Woolfort
I ſent you into England, and there placed you
With a brave Flanders Merchant, call'd rich Goſwin,
A man ſupplyed by me unto that purpoſe,
As bound by oath never to diſcover you,
Who dying, left his name and wealth unto you
As his reputed Son, and yet receiv'd ſo;
But now, is Florez, and a Prince, remember
The countreys, and the ſubjects generall good
Muſt challenge the firſt part in your affection:
The faire maid, whom you choſe to be your wife,
Being ſo far beneath you, that your love
Muſt grant ſhee's not your equall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In diſcent
Or borrowed glories, from dead Anceſtors,
But for her beauty, chaſtity, and all vertues
Ever remembred in the beſt of women,
A Monarch might receive from her, not give,
Though ſhe were his Crownes purchaſe; In this only
Be an indulgent Father: in all elſe,
Uſe my authority.

div.stage: Enter Hubert, Hemskirke, Woolfort, Bertha and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, here be two of 'em,
The Father and the Son, the reſt you ſhall have
As faſt as I can rouze them.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who's this? Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I Criple, your faigned crutches wil not help you,
Nor patch'd diſguiſe that hath ſo long conceal'd you,
It's now no halting. I muſt here finde Gerrard,
And in this Merch●nts habit, one called Florez
Who would be an Earl.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And is, wert thou a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this that Traitor Woolfo●t?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Yes, but you
Are they that are betraid: Hemskirke;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Goſwin
Turn'd Prince? ô I am poorer by this greatneſſe,
Then all my former jealouſies or misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Stay Sir, you were to day too neare her,
You muſt no more ayme at thoſe eaſy acceſſes,
Leſſe you can do 't in aire, without a head,
Which ſhall be ſodainly tri'de.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O take my heart, firſt,
And ſince I cannot hope now to enjoy him,
Let me but fall a part of his glad ranſome.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: You know not your own value, that entreat

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So proud a fiend as Woolfort.

sp.speaker: VVoolf.
sp.l: For ſo loſt
A thing as Florez.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And that would be ſo
Rather then ſhe ſhould ſtoop againe to thee;
There is no death, but's ſweeter then all life,
When VVoolfort is to give it: O my Gertrude,
It is not that, nor Prince dome that I goe from,
It is from thee, that loſſe includeth all.

sp.speaker: Wool
sp.l: I, if my young Prince knew his loſſe, hee would ſay ſo,
VVhich that he yet may chew on, I will tell him
This is no Gertrude, nor no Hemskirks Niece,
Nor Vandoncks daughter; this is Bertha, Bertha,
The heir of Brabant, ſhe that caus'd the warr,
Whom I did ſteale, during my treaty there,
For your minority, to raiſe my ſelfe;
I then fore-ſeeing 'twould beget a quarrell.
That, a neceſſity of my employment,
The ſame employment, make me maſter of ſtrength,
That ſtrength, the Lord of Flanders, ſo of Brabant,
By marrying her: which had not been to doe Sir,
She come of years, but that the expectation
Firſt of her Fathers death, retarded it,
And ſince the ſtanding out of Bruges, where
Hemskirke had hid her, till ſhe was neer loſt:
But Sir, we have recover'd her: your Merchantſhip
May breake, for this was one of your beſt bottoms
I thinke

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Inſolent Devill!

div.stage: Enter Hubert, with Jaqueline, Gynks and Coſtin.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who are theſe, Hemskirke?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: More, more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How they triumph in their treachery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Lord Arnold of Benthuſin, this Lord Coſtin,
This Jaqueline the ſiſter unto Florez.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: All found? why here's brave game, this was ſport-royall,
And puts me in thought of a new kind of death for 'em.
Huntſ-man, your horn: firſt wind me Florez fall,
Next Gerrards, then his daughter Jaquelins,
Thoſe raſcalls, they ſhall dye without their rights:
Hang 'em Hemskirke on theſe trees; Il'e take
The aſſay of theſe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Not here my Lord,
Let 'em be broken up, upon a ſcaffold,
Twill ſhew the better when their arbour's made.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Wretch art thou not content thou haſt betraid us
But mocke us too?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: Falſe Hubert, this is monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: VVho, this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes, this is Hubert, Woolfort,
I hope he ha's helpt himſelfe to a tree.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: The firſt,
The firſt of any, and moſt glad I have you Sir,
I let you goe before, but for a traine;
Is't you have done this ſervice?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As your Huntſ-man,
But now as Hubert; ſave your ſelves, I will,
The Woolf's a foote, let ſlip; kill, kill, kill, kill.

div.stage: Enter with a drum Van-donck, Merchants, Higgen, Prig, Ferret, Snap.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Betray'd?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, but well catch'd and I the Huntſman.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: How do you Woolfort? Raſcal, good knave Wool:
I ſpeake it now without the Roſe, and Hemskirck,
Rogue Hemskirck, you that have no neice, this Lady
Was ſtolen by you, and tane by you, and now
Reſign'd by me, to the right owner here:
Take her my Prince.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can this be poſſible,
Welcom my love, my ſweet, my worthy love.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: I ha' giv'n you her twice: now keep her better & thanke
Lord Hubert, that came to me in Gerrards name,
And got me out, with my brave Boyes, to march
Like Caeſar, when he bred his Comentaryes,
So I, to end my Chronicle, came forth
Give me my Bottle, and ſet downe the drum;
You had your tricks Sir, had you? we ha' tricks too,
You ſtole the Lady?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And we led your Squadrons
Where they ha' ſcratch'd their leggs a little, with brambles,
If not their faces.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Yes, and run their heads
Againſt trees.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis Captaine Prig, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And Coronell Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We have fill'd a pitt with your people ſome with leggs
Some with armes broken, and a neck, or two
I think be looſe.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The reſt too, that eſcap'd,
Are not yet out o'the briars,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And your horſes, Sir,
Are well ſet up in Bruges all by this time:
You looke as you were not well Sir, and would be
Shortly let blood; do you want a ſcarfe?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A halter.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Twas like your ſelfe, honeſt, and noble Hubert:
Can'ſt thou behold theſe mirrors altogether,
Of thy long, falſe, and bloody uſurpation?
Thy tyrranous proſcription, and freſh treaſon:
And not ſo ſee thy ſelfe, as to fall downe
And ſincking, force a grave, with thine owne guilt,
As deep as hell, to couer thee and it?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: No, I can ſtand: and praiſe the toyles that tooke me
And laughing in them dye, they were brave ſnares.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twer truer valour, if thou durſt repent
The wrongs th' haſt don, and live.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who, I repent?
And ſay I am ſorry? yes, 'tis the fooles language
And not fot Woolfort.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Woolfort thou art a Divell,
And ſpeaks his language, oh that I had my longing
Under this rew of trees now would I hang him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him live, untill he can repent,
But baniſh'd from our State, that is thy doome.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Then hang his worthy Captaine here, this Hemskirck
For profit of th' example.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him,
Enjoy his ſhame too: with his conſcious life,
To ſhew how much our innocence contemnes;
All practiſe from the guiltieſt, to moleſt us.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A noble prince.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt helpe to joyne
A paire of hands, as they have don their heartes here,
And to their loves with joy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As to mine owne,
My gratious Siſter, worthieſt Brother:

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'le go afore, and have the bon-fire made,
My fire-workes, and flap dragons, and good backrack,
With a peck of little fiſhes, to drink downe
In healthes to this day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Slight, here be changes,
The Bells ha' not ſo many, nor a dance, ●rig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Our Company's growne horrible thin by it,
What think you Ferret?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Marry I do thinke,
That we might all be Lords now, if we could ſtand for't

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not I if they ſhould offer it: I'le diſlodge firſt,
Remove the Buſh to another climat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt thanke this worthy Burgomaſter,
Here be friends aske to be look'd on too:
And thank'd, who though their trade, and courſe of life
Be not ſo perfect, but it may be betterd,
Have yet us'd me with curteſy, and bin true
Subjects unto me, while I was their King,
A place I know not well, how to reſigne.
Nor unto whom: But this I will entreat
Your grace, command them, follow me to Bruges;
Where I will take the care on me, to finde
Some manly, and more profitable courſe
To fit them, as a part of the Republique.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do you heare Sirs? do ſo.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thankes to your good grace.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your good Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: May you both live long.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Attend me at Van-doncks, the Burgomaſters. Ex. all but Beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, to beat hemp, and be whipt twice a weeke,
Or turne the wheele, for Crab the Rope-maker:
Or learne to go along with him, his courſe;
That's a fine courſe now, i' the Common-wealth, Prig,
What ſay you to it?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It is the backwardſt courſe,
I know i'the world.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then Higgen will ſcarce thrive by it,
You do conclude?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: 'Faith hardly, very hardly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Troth I am partly of your minde, Prince Prig.
And therefore farewell Flanders, Higgen will ſeek
Some ſafer ſhelter, in ſome other Clymat:
With this his tatterd Colony: Let me ſee
Snap, Ferret, Prig, and Higgen, all are left
O the true blood: what? ſhall we into England?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Agreed,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then beare up bravely with your Brute my lads
Higgen hath prig'd the prancers in his dayes,
And ſold good peny-worthes; we will have a courſe,
The ſpirit of Bottom, is growne bottomleſſe.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'le mand no more, nor cant.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, your ſixpenyworth
In private, brother, ſixpence is a ſumm,
I'le ſteale you any mans dogg for

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: For Sixpence more,
You'l tell the owner where he is.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Tis right,
Higgen muſt practiſe, ſo muſt Prig to eat;
And write the Letter: and gi' the word, But now
No more, as either of theſe.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: But as true Beggars,
As ere we were.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We ſtand here, for an Epilogue;
Ladyes, your bountyes firſt; the reſt will follow,
For womens favours, are a leading almes,
If you be pleas'd look cheerely throw your eyes:
Out at your maskes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And let your beauties ſparkle.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: So may you neer want dreſſings, Iewells, gownes
Still i' the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nor the men you love,
VVealth nor diſcourſe to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May you Gentlemen,
Never want good freſh ſuites nor liberty.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: May every Merchant here ſee ſafe his ventures.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And every honeſt Citizen his debts in.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The Lawyers gaine good Clyents.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And the Clyents good Councell.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: All the Gameſters here good fortune.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Drunkards too good wine.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The eaters meate
Fit for their taſts and pallats.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The good wives kind Husbands.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The young maides choyce of Sutors.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Midwives merry hearts.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And all good cheere.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: As you are kinde unto us and our Buſh,
We are the Beggars and your dayly Beadſmen,
And have your money, but the Almes we aske
And live by, is your Grace, give that and then
VV'eel boldly ſay our word is, Come agen.
